{{for|the 2015 French documentary film|Je suis Charlie (film)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{italic title}} [[File:Je suis Charlie.svg|thumb|The standard layout, as copied from the ''[[Charlie Hebdo]]'' site]] [[File:Charlie Hebdo Tout est pardonné.jpg|thumb|right|The front cover of [[Charlie Hebdo "Survivors' issue"|edition of 14 January 2015]], with a cartoon in the same style as 3 November 2011 cover, uses the phrase "''Je suis Charlie''"<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/11343077/How-I-created-the-Charlie-Hebdo-magazine-cover-cartoonist-Luzs-statement-in-full.html|title=How I created the Charlie Hebdo magazine cover: cartoonist Luz's statement in full|work=The Telegraph|date=13 January 2015}}</ref>]] [[File:Je Suis Charlie - Französische Botschaft Berlin 2.JPG|thumb|Slogan projected on the [[Embassy of France, Berlin|French embassy in Berlin]]]] [[File:Je suis Charlie Strasbourg 7 janvier 2015 02.jpg|right|thumb|January, 7 in [[Strasbourg]]]] [[File:Je suis Charlie, Brussels 11 January 2015 (123).jpg|thumb|"''Je suis Charlie''" in many languages in [[Brussels]], {{Nowrap|11 January 2015}}]] [[File:Marche du 11 Janvier 2015, Paris (2).jpg|thumb|With symbols of the three main [[Abrahamic religions]]]] [[File:Global Debout - Place de la République, 2016.05.15 (4).jpg|thumb|Place de la République, Paris]]
"'''''{{lang|fr|Je suis Charlie}}'''''" ({{IPA-fr|ʒə sɥi ʃaʁli}}, {{Language with name/for|2=French|3="I am Charlie"}}) is a slogan and logo created by French art director Joachim Roncin and adopted by supporters of [[freedom of speech]] and [[freedom of the press]] after the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|7 January 2015 shooting]] in which twelve people were killed at the offices of the French satirical weekly newspaper ''[[Charlie Hebdo]]''. It identifies a speaker or supporter with those who were killed at the ''Charlie Hebdo'' shooting, and by extension, a supporter of freedom of speech and resistance to armed threats. Some journalists embraced the expression as a rallying cry for the freedom of self-expression.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://enisyavuz.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/jesuis05.png |title=image |publisher=enisyavuz.com |accessdate=8 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109002354/http://enisyavuz.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/jesuis05.png |archivedate= 9 January 2015 |df= }}</ref>
The slogan was first used on Twitter. The website of ''Charlie Hebdo'' went offline shortly after the shooting and when it became live again, it bore the legend ''Je suis Charlie'' on a black background,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.charliehebdo.fr |title=Charlie Hedbo Official Website |date=7 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107120424/http://www.charliehebdo.fr/ |archivedate=7 January 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> a [[PDF]] containing translations in seven languages was added shortly thereafter.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150108050610/http://www.charliehebdo.fr/20150107171028368.pdf Archive of Charlie Hebdo ''Je suis Charlie'' translations pdf]</ref> The statement was used as the [[hashtag]] #jesuischarlie and #iamcharlie<ref name=Cormack20150108>{{cite news|last1=Cormack|first1=Lucy|title=Paris terrorist attack: Charlie Hebdo shooting video provokes social media backlash|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/paris-terrorist-attack-charlie-hebdo-shooting-video-provokes-social-media-backlash-20150108-12jvhf.html|accessdate=9 January 2015|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=8 January 2015}}</ref> on Twitter,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/je-suis-charlie-trends-people-4935086|work=Daily Mirror|title='Je suis Charlie' trends as people refuse to be silenced by Charlie Hebdo gunmen|author=Richard Booth|date=7 January 2015}}</ref> as computer printed or hand-made placards and stickers, and displayed on mobile phones at vigils, and on many websites, particularly media sites.
Within two days of the attack, the slogan had become one of the most popular news hashtags in Twitter history.<ref name="twitter">{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/01/09/technology/social/jesuischarlie-hashtag-twitter/index.html |title=#JeSuisCharlie becomes one of most popular hashtags in Twitter's history|work=[[CNNMoney]]|date=9 January 2015|accessdate=12 January 2015|author1=David Goldman |author2=Jose Pagliery}}</ref> ''Je suis Charlie'' was adopted worldwide, was used in music, displayed in print and animated cartoons (including ''[[The Simpsons]]''), and became the new name of a town square in France.
On 12 January, ''Charlie Hebdo'' revealed the cover of its 14 January issue, set to be published a week after the attacks began. The cover features a cartoon of the Islamic prophet [[Muhammad]] shedding a tear while holding a ''Je suis Charlie'' sign, above the words ''"Tout est pardonné"'' ("All is forgiven").<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/comic-riffs/wp/2015/01/12/charlie-hebdo-reveals-next-cover-a-cartoon-of-prophet-muhammad-behind-the-sign-je-suis-charlie/ |title=Charlie Hebdo reveals first cover since attack: A 'prophet Muhammad' caricature, crying behind the sign, 'Je suis Charlie' |work=[[The Washington Post]] |author= Michael Cavna |date=12 January 2015}}</ref>
==Origin and meaning== About one hour after the attack, an image of the slogan was posted to Twitter by Joachim Roncin,<ref>{{Cite news |title=#JeSuisCharlie creator: Phrase cannot be a trademark |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-30797059 |publisher=BBC News |date=14 January 2015 |accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> a French artist and music journalist for ''[[Stylist (magazine)|Stylist]]'' magazine. Roncin says he created the image because he lacked words.<ref>{{cite news |first=Lauren |last=Provost |date=7 January 2015 |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.fr/2015/01/07/je-suis-charlie-origine-createur-joachim-roncin-slogan-logo-solidarite-charlie-hebdo_n_6431084.html |title=Je suis Charlie: qui est à l'origine de l'image et du slogan que le monde entier reprend par solidarité |language=French |newspaper=The Huffington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/secteur/high-tech/2015/01/08/01007-20150108ARTFIG00160-jesuischarlie-trois-mots-pour-symboliser-l-emotion-d-une-planete.php |title=#JeSuisCharlie utilisé dans plus de 3,5 millions de tweets |work=[[Le Figaro]] |language=French}}</ref> Roncin said the phrase came to him naturally, because he regularly spends time with his son looking at ''Où est Charlie?'' books (the French language version of ''[[Where's Wally?]]'').<ref name="20minutes">{{cite news |url=http://www.20minutes.fr/medias/1512635-20150108-attaque-charlie-hebdo-jesuischarlie-histoire-cri-liberte |title=Un directeur artistique, à l'origine du slogan |work=[[20 minutes (France)|20 Minutes]] |date=8 January 2015}}.</ref>
The slogan is intended to evoke solidarity with the victims, as other similar phrases have done. Such "I am" and "We are" slogans "express empathy, outrage, and horror by subsuming ourselves into victims' identities", wrote Amanda Hess of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''.<ref name="iam">{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2015/01/_jesuischarlie_the_default_mode_of_showing_solidarity_in_the_hashtag_age.html |title=#IAm: The default mode of showing solidarity in the hashtag era |author=Amanda Hess |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=9 January 2015 |accessdate=12 January 2015}}</ref> French media in particular noted its similarity to the phrase "Tonight, we are all Americans," (''"Ce soir, nous sommes tous Américains"'') spoken on air by [[France 2]] reporter [[Nicole Bacharan]] on the evening of 11 September 2001.<ref name="20minutes" /> The phrase was widely embraced, including being printed on the front page of French newspaper ''[[Le Monde]]'' the following day. ''Je suis Charlie'' has also been compared to another phrase of solidarity, "''[[Ich bin ein Berliner]]''" ("I am a Berliner"), a declaration by U.S. President [[John F. Kennedy]] on 26 June 1963, in West Berlin on the 15th anniversary of the Berlin blockade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.fr/story/96697/critiques-slogan-je-suis-charlie |title="Je suis Charlie", le bon slogan au bon moment |trans-title='Je suis Charlie', the right slogan at the right time| author=Xavier Landes |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=12 January 2015|language=fr}}</ref>
Media also have drawn comparisons to the iconic "I'm Spartacus" scene in the film ''[[Spartacus (film)|Spartacus]]'' (1960),<ref name="managementtoday">{{cite web |url=http://www.managementtoday.co.uk/opinion/1328478/we-not-charlie-hebdo/ |title=We are not Charlie Hebdo: Opinion |publisher=managementtoday.co.uk |accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> the "[[I Am a Man!]]" slogan used during African American civil rights marches in 1968, or the use of "I am Michael Brown" after the [[shooting of Michael Brown]] in 2014.<ref name="I am slogan"/> <!-- not supported by any reference: as well as more recent protests slogans and trending hashtags like "[[We are the 99%]]" and "[[Trayvon Martin|I am Trayvon Martin]]", "[[Death of Eric Garner|I can't breathe]]". --> The phrase is also similar to "Main hoon aam aadmi" meaning "I am the common man" slogan used by the [[Aam Aadmi Party]] in India.<ref name="iam" />
===Reaction to violence against journalists=== [[File:Lines Against Terror.jpg|thumb|Indian cartoonist [[Shekhar Gurera]] along with his fellow cartoonists protested and expressed solidarity with victims of attack by drawing their creations at the [[Press club]] of [[India]], New Delhi on 9 January 2015]] [[File:Marche hommage Charlie hebdo et aux victimes des attentats de janvier 2015 (9).jpg|thumb|With "''Liberté de la Presse''" ([[Freedom of the press]]) in Paris on {{Nowrap|11 January 2015}}]] Beyond expressing sympathy for the victims, within hours of the attack the hashtag was used by journalists discussing the issue of censorship and threats. Sophie Kleeman of [[Mic (media company)|Mic]] wrote, "#JeSuisCharlie sends a clear message: Regardless of the threat of hatred or violence, journalists and non-journalists alike refuse to be silenced. As [[Charb]]onnier said in 2012, following the firebombing of his offices, 'I have neither a wife nor children, not even a dog. But I'm not going to hide.'"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mic.com/articles/107888/je-suis-charlie-stands-up-for-free-speech-after-attack-on-french-magazine |title=#JeSuisCharlie Stands Up for Free Speech After Deadly Attack on French Magazine |author=Sophie Kleeman |date=7 January 2015|publisher=Mic}}</ref>
In the opinion of Gene Policinski, chief operating officer of the [[Newseum|Newseum Institute]] and Senior Vice-President of the [[First Amendment Center]], the ''Charlie Hebdo'' killings were part of a string of recent threats toward journalists and freedom of speech, following [[Sony Pictures Entertainment hack|North Korea's threats]] over the release of the film ''[[The Interview]]'' (2014) and [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIL]]'s executions of journalists. In his opinion, Policinski stated that instead of being successful at silencing anyone, these attempts at censorship and the Paris massacre have backfired and instead brought more awareness and support to freedom of speech. "Ironically, such violence directed at journalists, authors and others is recognition that free expression and the marketplace of ideas—enshrined in the U.S. [Constitution] in the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]]—is a powerful weapon against tyranny", he wrote; "For more than 220 years, in the U.S., the 45 words of the First Amendment have defined the nation's core freedoms of religion, speech, press, assembly and petition. We now have another few words that will serve as a global means of declaring those freedoms: #JeSuisCharlie."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gazettextra.com/20150107/first_amendment_jesuischarlie8212another_way_to_say_8216freedom8217 |title=First Amendment: #JeSuisCharlie—another way to say 'freedom' |author=Gene Policinski |publisher=Gazette Extra |date=7 January 2015}}</ref>
Journalist Peter Bella wrote that more than 100 reporters were killed "doing their jobs" in 2014 and that "many were executed just because they were journalists." He said the hashtag "was created to support ''Charlie Hebdo'', the victims, and freedom of the press, speech, and expression. I am Charlie. You are Charlie. We are all Charlie."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagonow.com/interesting-chicago/2015/01/jesuischarlie-the-price-of-freedom-is-never-too-high |title=#JeSuisCharlie: The price of freedom is never too high |author=Peter Bella |publisher=ChicagoNow|date=7 January 2015}}</ref>
===''"Je ne suis pas Charlie"''=== Counter-hashtags also appeared as expressions of disagreement with the unconditional support of ''Charlie Hebdo''. The hashtag #JeNeSuisPasCharlie ("I am not Charlie") was used by those who accuse the magazine of racism.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://stream.aljazeera.com/story/201501081423-0024476|title=Charlie Hebdo hashtags reveal defiance, solidarity and Islamophobia |first=Gene |last=Policinski |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=8 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://rue89.nouvelobs.com/2015/01/08/jenesuispascharlie-a-rebours-lemotion-collective-twitter-256969|title=#JeNeSuisPasCharlie : à rebours de l'émotion collective sur Twitter |author=Hadrien Bajolle |publisher=L'Oubs |date=8 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=bbcnews>{{cite news |title=Why the popularity of #killallmuslims is not all it seems |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-trending-30728491|accessdate=8 January 2015 |publisher=BBC News|date=8 January 2015}}</ref> ''Le Monde'' reported that a fake bomb was left in the faculty lounge of a French high school containing the message: "Je ne suis pas Charlie".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2015/01/10/a-saint-denis-collegiens-et-lyceens-ne-sont-pas-tous-charlie_4553048_3224.html |title=A Saint-Denis, collégiens et lycéens ne sont pas tous " Charlie "|first1=Mattea |last1=Battaglia |first2=Benoit |last2=Floc'h |publisher=Le Monde.fr}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.francetvinfo.fr/faits-divers/attaque-au-siege-de-charlie-hebdo/minute-de-silence-pour-charlie-hebdo-la-difficile-tache-des-profs-dans-certains-colleges_792855.html |title=On ne va pas se laisser insulter par un dessin du prophète, c'est normal qu'on se venge|author=Francetv info |work=francetv info}}</ref> In an article titled "I Am Not Charlie Hebdo" published in ''[[The New York Times]]'', American journalist [[David Brooks (journalist)|David Brooks]], while describing the journalists at ''Charlie Hebdo'' as "martyrs on behalf of freedom of expression," described ''Charlie Hebdo'' as a puerile magazine whose offensive humor would be labelled as [[hate speech]] in the United States.<ref>{{cite web |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/09/opinion/david-brooks-i-am-not-charlie-hebdo.html|title=I Am Not Charlie Hebdo |first=David |last=Brooks |date=8 January 2015}}</ref> News media also used the slogan "Je ne suis pas Charlie" to discuss why they chose not to publish any ''Charlie Hebdo'' cartoons as part of their news reporting.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://nowtoronto.com/news/free-speech-advocates-can%27t-guilt-trip-me/ |title=Free speech advocates can't guilt-trip me |work=NOW Magazine |accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref> Others used the "Je ne suis pas Charlie" slogan to make a comparison between the loud outcry over the attacks in Paris, and the comparatively smaller outcry over other atrocities going on in non-Western countries that took place at the same time.<ref>{{cite book |publisher=Christian Today |url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/david.robertson.je.ne.suis.pas.charlie.je.suis.charlene/46107.htm |title=David Robertson: Je ne suis pas Charlie, Je suis Charlene |accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref> While condemning the murders of the 17 people in Paris, British [[Respect Party|Respect]] politician [[George Galloway]] considered the Charlie cartoons to be "pornographic, obscene insults to the Prophet and by extension, 1.7 billion humans".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Selby|first1=Jenn|title=George Galloway condemns 'racist, Islamophobic, hypocritical rag' Charlie Hebdo at freedom of speech rally|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/george-galloway-condemns-racist-islamophobic-hypocritical-rag-charlie-hebdo-at-freedom-of-speech-rally-9990490.html|accessdate=12 March 2015|work=The Independent|date=20 January 2015}}</ref>
===Other criticism=== In a ''[[The New Yorker]]'' essay, [[Teju Cole]] objected to the claim that ''Charlie Hebdo'' cartoonists and writers were equal opportunity offenders; to him, the magazine, in recent years, had taken a turn "specifically for racist and Islamophobic provocations (...) featuring hook-nosed Arabs, bullet-ridden Korans, variations on the theme of sodomy, and mockery of the victims of a massacre". Furthermore, he also posited that the outpouring of support for ''Charlie Hebdo'' was only possible because the attack fits in a pre-established narrative wherein Western lives are worth more, and which sees that violence that befalls the Third World and/or has Western allies as accomplices is paid comparatively little attention. Cole also rebuked the view that "violence by self-proclaimed Jihadists is the only threat to liberty in Western societies", stating that the very governments of France, the US, and the UK undermine free speech within their own societies via monitoring and punishment of dissidents and critics of the state.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/cultural-comment/unmournable-bodies |title=Unmournable Bodies |last1=Cole |first1=Teju |date= 9 January 2015|website=The New Yorker|access-date= 21 January 2016}}</ref> Cole was among the writers who boycotted the [[PEN American Center]]'s May 2015 gala as an award to ''Charlie Hebdo'' was due to be presented at the ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/apr/27/peter-carey-among-writers-to-protest-pen-honour-for-charlie-hebdo|date=27 April 2015|work=The Guardian|title=Peter Carey among writers to protest PEN honour for Charlie Hebdo}}</ref>
[[Glenn Greenwald]] accused supporters of ''Je Suis Charlie'' of either keeping silence about, or downright supporting, what he sees as free speech violations perpetrated by the French state in the year that followed the massacre, including the following events: the arrest of comedian [[Dieudonné M'bala M'bala]] for hate speech, and of further dozens of people for "acts insulting religious faiths, or for cheering the men who carried out the attacks"; the criminal conviction, by France's highest court, of pro-Palestinian protesters for having advocated a [[Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions|boycott of Israeli products]] at a supermarket; the shutting down of mosques and coffee shops; and France's use of "emergency powers", after the [[November 2015 Paris attacks]], to ban a rally by environmental activists in protest to the [[2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] which was taking place in the French capital. He has accused most ''Je Suis Charlie'' supporters of being, not true advocates of free speech rights, but anti-Muslim agitators who used the massacre at the magazine's headquarters as a "cynical weapon".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://theintercept.com/2016/01/08/where-were-the-post-hebdo-free-speech-crusaders-as-france-spent-the-last-year-crushing-free-speech/ |title=Where Were the Post-Hebdo Free Speech Crusaders as France Spent the Last Year Crushing Free Speech? |last1=Greenwald |first1=Glenn|date=8 January 2016 |website=[[The Intercept]]|access-date=21 January 2016}}</ref> Greenwald has cited in his support the work of French sociologist [[Emmanuel Todd]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://theintercept.com/2015/10/27/criminalization-of-anti-israel-activism-escalates-this-time-in-the-land-of-the-charlie-hebdo-free-speech-march/|title=Anti-Israel Activism Criminalized in the Land of Charlie Hebdo and "Free Speech" |last1=Greenwald |first1=Glenn|date=27 October 2015 |website=[[The Intercept]]|access-date=21 January 2016}}</ref> Todd claims that the marches on 11 January 2015 to show solidarity with the ''Charlie Hebdo'' victims were not an expression of positive French values but of right-wing and anti-immigrant elements in France. The biggest of such protests, says Todd, "had occurred in the country's most historically Catholic and reactionary regions", with the working class and children of immigrants being notably absent therefrom. In 2015 Todd published a book expanding on his view named ''Qui est Charlie? Sociologie d'une crise religieuse'' ("Who is Charlie? Sociology of a religious crisis"), which has become his most controversial and popular essay.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/aug/28/emmanuel-todd-the-french-thinker-who-wont-toe-the-charlie-hebdo-line|title=Emmanuel Todd: the French thinker who won't toe the Charlie Hebdo line|work=The Guardian|date=28 August 2015}}</ref>
==Usage==
===Twitter===
''Je suis Charlie'' trended at the top of Twitter hashtags on 7 January, the day of the attack. By the following afternoon it had appeared more than 3.4 million times, and was being used nearly 6,500 times per minute.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Whitehead|first1=Tom|title=Paris Charlie Hebdo attack: Je Suis Charlie hashtag one of most popular in Twitter history|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/11336879/Paris-Charlie-Hebdo-attack-Je-Suis-Charlie-hashtag-one-of-most-popular-in-Twitter-history.html|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=9 January 2015}}</ref> By Friday, it had appeared more than 5 million times.<ref name="twitter" />
The senior bishop in England, [[Archbishop of Canterbury]] [[Justin Welby]], was among those who tweeted the hashtag, and wrote in French: "The response to such demonic violence is love for those who suffer and virtuous action against evil".<ref name="I am slogan">[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2900720/JeSuisCharlie-sweeps-Twitter-Internet-users-rush-solidarity-French-satirical-news-magazine-massacre.html "#JeSuisCharlie sweeps Twitter as Internet users rush to show solidarity with French satirical news magazine after massacre"]. ''Daily Mail''. Retrieved 13 January 2014</ref>
The [[Embassy of the United States, Paris|U.S. Embassy in Paris]] and the [[Association française pour le nommage Internet en coopération]] were among the people and organizations which changed their Twitter profile pictures to the ''Je suis Charlie'' placard.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rt.com/news/220659-support-charlie-hedbo-world |title=#JeSuisCharlie: World stands with Charlie Hebdo victims |publisher=RT|location=Russia |date=7 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=AFNIC>{{cite news|title=A secret message of support for Charlie Hebdo built into French Web sites|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2015/01/09/a-secret-message-of-support-for-charlie-hedbo-built-into-french-web-sites/|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=9 January 2015}}</ref>

Others used it in combination with pictures of the deceased.<ref name="cnn-smedia">{{cite news |publisher=[[CNN]] |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/01/07/world/social-media-jesuischarlie/ |title=#JeSuisCharlie – Solidarity on social media for press freedom, terror victims |author1=Ashley Fantz |author2=Hilary Whiteman |date=8 January 2015 |accessdate=8 January 2015}}</ref> * The magazine ''Charlie Hebdo'' had used the name [[Charlie Brown]] from the ''[[Peanuts]]'' comic strip, and an image of Charlie Brown crying with the slogan was posted on Twitter.<ref name="cnn-smedia"/> * ''[[The Canberra Times]]''' political cartoonist David Pope released an image of a smoking gun, with a gunman saying, "He drew first."<ref name="cnn-smedia"/> * Cartoonist James MacLeod released an image of the power of the gun compared with the power of free speech.<ref name="cnn-smedia"/> * Soshy released an image of a blood-dripping ''Je suis Charlie'' in front of the French flag.<ref name="cnn-smedia"/> * [[Albert Uderzo]], creator of [[Astérix]], came out of retirement aged 87 following the attack. ====Golden Globe Awards====
The [[72nd Golden Globe Awards]] show, held 11 January in Beverly Hills, was the first major entertainment event to take place after the killings. Prior to the awards show, film producer [[Harvey Weinstein]] penned a lengthy [[open letter]] to Hollywood in ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' about the attacks and the importance of free speech, writing that he hoped there would be displays of "solidarity" at the awards, before ending his letter with ''"Je suis Charlie, je suis juif, je suis Ahmed."'' ("I am Charlie, I am Jewish, I am Ahmed.")<ref>{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2015/01/harvey-weinstein-golden-globes-charle-hebdo-1201347423 |title=Harvey Weinstein on Golden Globes Hope For Charlie Hebdo Solidarity |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|author= Mike Fleming Jr. |date=11 January 2015 |accessdate=12 January 2015}}</ref>
At the show, stars including [[George Clooney|George]] and [[Amal Clooney]], [[Kathy Bates]], [[Helen Mirren]], [[Diane Kruger]], [[Joshua Jackson]] and [[William H. Macy]], wore ''Je Suis Charlie'' on pins affixed to their clothes or handbags, held signs with the slogan or used the phrase in [[red carpet]] interviews.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.today.com/popculture/golden-globes-2015-jesuischarlie-red-carpet-george-clooney-helen-mirren-1D80418437 |title=#JeSuisCharlie: Stars support victims of Paris attacks at Golden Globes |publisher=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today.com]] |author=Emily Sher |date=11 January 2015|accessdate=12 January 2015}}</ref> In his acceptance speech for the [[Golden Globe Cecil B. DeMille Award|Cecil B. DeMille Award]], George Clooney wore a ''Je suis Charlie'' pin on his lapel and said, "Millions of people – not just in Paris but around the world, Christians and Jews and Muslims, leaders of countries all over the world – they didn't march in protest, they marched in support of the idea that we will not walk in fear. We won't do it. So ''Je suis Charlie.''" [[Jared Leto]] used the term in a speech before presenting an award.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2015/01/george-clooney-charlie-hebdo-golden-globes-1201347473 |title=Golden Globes: George Clooney, Jared Leto Say 'Je Suis Charlie' |author1=Jen Yamato |author2=Anthony D'Alessandro|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=11 January 2015|accessdate=12 January 2015}}</ref>
===Sports=== * Two French [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] players wore T-shirts bearing the motto during pregame warmups: [[Nicolas Batum]] of the [[Portland Trail Blazers]] on 8 January<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nba-ball-dont-lie/nicolas-batum-wears--je-suis-charlie--warmup-shirt-before-blazers-heat-034021262.html |title=Nicolas Batum wears 'Je Suis Charlie' warmup shirt before Blazers-Heat |first=Dan |last=Devine |work=Ball Don't Lie |publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]] |date=8 January 2015 |accessdate=11 January 2015}}</ref> and [[Kevin Séraphin]] of the [[Washington Wizards]] the next night.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nba/story/_/id/12144163/kevin-seraphin-washington-wizards-dons-je-suis-charlie-t-shirt-warm-ups |title=Kevin Seraphin dons 'Charlie' shirt |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=10 January 2015 |accessdate=11 January 2015}}</ref> * Italian football club [[S.S. Lazio]] wore the motto on their uniforms during a match on 11 January against [[A.S. Roma]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Lazio wear special 'Je Suis Charlie' shirts against Roma in show of solidarity with Paris after terrorist attacks|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/01/11/lazio-wear-special-je-suis-charlie-shirts-against-roma-in-show-of-solidarity-with-paris-after-terrorist-attacks-5018021/|accessdate=12 January 2015|publisher=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|date=11 January 2015}}</ref> * Supporters of [[Olympique de Marseille]] cheered under a screen displaying the words ''Je suis Charlie'' before their football match on 9 January in [[Montpellier]], France.<ref>{{cite web|title=Marseille's supporters cheer under a screen displaying the words ''Je suis Charlie'' in tribute to the victims of an attack on Charlie Hebdo |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/photos/marseilles-supporters-cheer-under-screen-displaying-words-je-photo-221717889--sow.html |website=Yahoo Sports |accessdate=12 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150112142941/http://sports.yahoo.com/photos/marseilles-supporters-cheer-under-screen-displaying-words-je-photo-221717889--sow.html |archivedate=12 January 2015 |df= }}</ref> * On 12 January 2015, during the game of the [[Rethymno Cretan Kings B.C.]] against the [[Aries Trikala B.C.]] for the [[Greek Basket League]], the [[cheerleaders]] and the [[mascot]] of the home team wore T-shirts bearing the motto.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ρέθυμνο Aegean: "Je suis Charlie" |url=http://www.rethymnobc.gr/nea-anakoinoseis/page/20/articles/rethumno-aegean-je-suis-charlie.html |website=rethymnobc.gr/ |accessdate=12 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117032123/http://www.rethymnobc.gr/nea-anakoinoseis/page/20/articles/rethumno-aegean-je-suis-charlie.html |archivedate=17 November 2015 |df= }}</ref> * On 13 January 2015, supporters of the Greek Volleyball team AON Pannaxiakos [[Naxos]] during the match against the French team Le Cannet for the [[CEV Women's Challenge Cup]] raised panels with the slogan "Je suis Charlie".<ref>{{cite web|title="Je suis Charlie" στη Νάξο|url=http://www.volleynews.gr/index.php/volleyleague-rm/lamia/item/25505-je-suis-charlie-%CF%83%CF%84%CE%B7-%CE%BD%CE%AC%CE%BE%CE%BF|website=volleynews.gr|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref>
===Exhibitions=== An exhibition titled "Je suis Charlie" honoring free expression was held in Drammen Theater on 27 February 2015. The exhibition which was arranged by the Universal Tolerance Organization featured 100 religious and political cartoons from 40 countries. Due to security concerns there were no cartoons of Mohammed and the exhibition only stayed open for six hours with heavily armed police present.<ref>Elin Sørsdahl and Ida Falck-Olsen (27 February 2015) [http://www.tv2.no/a/6626543 Politi med maskingevær vokter utstilling uten Muhammed-karikaturer] {{no icon}}TV2</ref>
===Place name=== The day after the attack, Jean-Pierre Tallieu, mayor of the city of [[La Tremblade]], in the suburb of [[Royan]], Charente-Maritime, named a public square "Je suis Charlie Place" to perpetuate the memory of the victims. A temporary plaque was inaugurated on 10 January<ref>[http://www.sudouest.fr/2015/01/09/charente-maritime-une-place-charlie-inauguree-a-la-tremblade-ce-samedi-1791387-1391.php Charente-Maritime : a "place Je suis Charlie" iinaugrated at La Tremblade This Sunday], article by Ronan Chérel in ''Sud Ouest'', 9 January 2015</ref> and will be permanently replaced once the paperwork is completed to register the new name.<ref>[http://www.leparisien.fr/bordeaux-33000/charente-maritime-une-place-baptisee-je-suis-charlie-a-la-tremblade-09-01-2015-4433085.php A place christened « Je suis Charlie » at La Tremblade], ''Le Parisien'', 9 January 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/321644089 osm])</ref>
===Software=== [[Notepad++]] version 6.7.4, released on 10 January 2015, was named '''''Je suis Charlie'''''. In response the website was hacked by the Tunisian Fallaga Team, accusing Notepad++ of calling Islam a terrorist religion.<ref>{{cite news |title=Notepad++ Site Hacked in Response to "Je suis Charlie" Edition |url=http://www.securityweek.com/notepad-site-hacked-response-%E2%80%9Cje-suis-charlie%E2%80%9D-edition |accessdate=21 January 2015 |work=Security Week |date=15 January 2015}}</ref> [[GNU parallel]]'s release 20150122 was named ''' ((:~{> Je Suis Charlie'''.<ref>{{cite news|title=GNU Parallel 20150122 (' (((:~{> Je Suis Charlie') released |url=https://savannah.gnu.org/forum/forum.php?forum_id=8184 |last=Tange |first=Ole |accessdate=30 January 2015 |publisher=Free Software Foundation |date=21 January 2015}}</ref>
Several developers produced applications for smartphones. On Android, apps appeared to display the various versions of the "Je suis Charlie" slogan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phonesreview.co.uk/2015/01/13/je-suis-charlie-app-for-android-and-iphone-shows-solidarity/|title=Je Suis Charlie app for Android and iPhone shows solidarity|work=Phones Review}}</ref> French developers from the news agency Nice-Matin launched a ''Je suis Charlie'' smartphone app for iOS and Android. Installing the free app and giving it access to the phone's location adds a dot on a map alongside other supporters. While new iOS apps typically take at least a week to be vetted, the agency e-mailed Apple CEO [[Tim Cook]] and the app was approved in one hour after the shootings.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/je-suis-charlie-app-shows-worldwide-support-french/story?id=28167153 |title='Je Suis Charlie' App Shows Worldwide Support for French Terror Attack Victims |author=Alyssa Newcomb |date=12 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://9to5mac.com/2015/01/12/je-suis-charlie-app/ |title=French app to show support for Je Suis Charlie campaign approved in one hour after contacting Tim Cook |work=9to5mac |date=12 January 2015}}</ref>
===Commercial use=== Within days of the attack, merchandise featuring ''Je suis Charlie'' was available for sale around the world. This led to critical questioning of whether businesses were profiting off the tragedy or simply responding to market demand.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/01/10/news/je-suis-charlie-merchandise/ |title=Retailers walk line with 'Je Suis Charlie' merchandise|work=[[CNNMoney]]|date=10 January 2015|accessdate=12 January 2015|author1=Cristina Alesci |author2=Kate Trafecante}}</ref> By 12 January, [[eBay]] had more than 5,000 items on its site, including T-shirts, mugs, artwork, pins, posters, hats, phone cases, keychains and dogtags. The auction company announced it would donate fees earned from ''Je suis Charlie''-related sales in France.<ref name="lemonde9jan">{{cite news|title= L'émergence d'un funeste business " Je suis Charlie " sur le Web|last= Tual|first= Morgane|url= http://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2015/01/09/l-emergence-d-un-funeste-business-je-suis-charlie-sur-le-web_4552164_3224.html|accessdate=11 January 2015|work=[[Le Monde]]|date=9 January 2015|language=French}}</ref>
On 8 January, French mail order company [[3 Suisses]] drew criticism for appropriating the slogan for social media self-promotion after tweeting an image with the words "Je ''Suisses'' Charlie." It removed the slogan the same day and apologized.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}}<!-- WP:RS needed; removed link to WP:SPS (Twitter, FB, WP)--> eBay stated it would remove any items featuring the slogan that were "inconsistent with its regulations, principles and values."<ref name="lemonde9jan" /> The Hoxton Hotel chain was criticized for including "#jesuischarile {{sic}}" in a Facebook post promoting its new Paris hotel. The firm later published a post saying its intent was only to show solidarity with Paris.<ref>{{cite news|title=London hotel group under fire for advertising its new Paris venture using 'je suis Charlie' hashtag in wake of terror attacks |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2906803/London-hotel-group-fire-advertising-new-Paris-venture-using-je-suis-Charlie-hashtag-wake-terror-attacks.html|accessdate=12 January 2015|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=13 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Hoxton hotel slammed for showing solidarity with Paris attack victims by 'shamelessly' promoting new hotel|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/hoxton-hotel-shows-solidarity-with-paris-attack-victims-by-shamelessly-promoting-new-hotel-9972902.html|accessdate=12 January 2015|work=[[The Independent]]|date=12 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Outrage after The Hoxton uses #JeSuisCharlie to promote new hotel |url=http://www.london24.com/news/outrage_after_trendy_hotel_uses_jesuischarlie_1_3913470 |accessdate=12 January 2015 |publisher=London 24 |date=12 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113033304/http://www.london24.com/news/outrage_after_trendy_hotel_uses_jesuischarlie_1_3913470 |archivedate=13 January 2015 |df= }}</ref>
The domain name jesuischarlie.com was registered on the same day as the attack and featured an automatic redirect to the ''Charlie Hebdo'' website. Jesuischarlie.net, jesuischarlie.fr and iamcharlie.fr were also registered but initially had no content.<ref name="lemonde9jan" />
A trademark application for the combination of words "Je suis Charlie" was filed at the Benelux Trademark Office on 8 January 2015 in the evening hours by Yanick Uytterhaegen of Brussels, who claims he wants to use the trademark to raise money for Charlie Hebdo.<ref>{{cite news|title=Charlie Hebdo: Belgian seeking to trademark "Je Suis Charlie" says he wants to help victims|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/charlie-hebdo-belgian-seeking-to-trademark-je-suis-charlie-says-he-wants-to-help-victims-9975783.html|accessdate=13 January 2015|work=The Independent|date=13 January 2015}}</ref> The trademark application covers several classes of the international classification including Classes 3, 25 35 and 38.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldipreview.com/|title=World IP Review|author=Newton Media|publisher=worldipreview.com}}</ref>
===Vandalism=== After the ''Charlie Hebdo'' shooting, a mosque in [[Bischwiller]], France, was vandalized with the graffiti, "Ich bin Charlie" ("I am Charlie", in German).<ref>{{cite news|title=French mosques targeted following Charlie Hebdo attack|url=http://www.euro-islam.info/2015/01/11/french-mosques-targeted-following-charlie-hebdo-attack/}}</ref>
==Echoes==
After the [[2015 Baga massacre|Baga Massacre]] the hashtag #Jesuisnigeria was used to express support for Nigeria as well as point out the lack of media coverage of the event compared to the Charlie Hebdo shooting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mike-shammas/je-suis-nigeria_b_6486518.html|title=Je Suis Nigeria|last=Shammas|first=Michael|date=16 January 2015|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=27 February 2017}}</ref>
Following the flogging of Saudi blogger [[Raif Badawi]] for the crimes of "insulting Islam", the hastag #Jesuisraif trended on Twitter.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-30902593|title=#FreeSpeechStories: The explosion of #JeSuis____ campaigns|date=20 January 2015|publisher=BBC News|access-date=27 February 2017|language=en-GB}}</ref>
The hashtag #jesuisahmed ("I am Ahmed") was used to express solidarity with [[Ahmed Merabet]], a Muslim police officer whose murder in the street by the attackers was captured on video.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://wishcrys.com/2015/01/09/jesuisahmed-speaks-back-to-jesuischarlie-on-instagram/|title=#JeSuisAhmed speaks back to #JeSuisCharlie on Instagram |author=Crystal Abidin |publisher=Wishcrys |date=9 January 2015}}</ref>
After [[Porte de Vincennes hostage crisis|the siege]] at the [[Kashrut|kosher]] [[Hypercacher]] supermarket in [[Vincennes]] on 9 January, the ''Je suis Hypercacher'' slogan was launched on an eponymous website after four hostages were shot dead.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}}<!-- WP:RS needed; removed link to WP:SPS (Twitter, FB, WP)--><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/je-suis-juif-trends-twitter-4949612|title='Je suis Juif' trends on Twitter after attack on kosher grocery in Paris|author=Richard Beech|date=9 January 2015|work=mirror}}</ref> As the victims were targeted on account of their Jewish religion, people tweet the hashtag #JeSuisJuif ("I am Jewish") in honor of the victims.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2015/01/09/je-suis-juif-paris-jewish-grocery_n_6444658.html|title=Victims at Jewish Grocery in Paris Honoured With #JeSuisJuif|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref>
Following [[Buhas bus attack|an attack on a bus]] on 13 January that killed 12 people near [[Volnovakha]], eastern Ukraine, Ukrainian President [[Petro Poroshenko]] posted an image on Facebook of a bullet-riddled bus above the caption ''Je Suis Volnovakha''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/Diaspora/Ukraine-jumps-on-Je-suis-Charlie-bandwagon-387856|title=Ukraine jumps on 'Je suis Charlie' bandwagon |date=15 January 2015|author=Sam Sokol|work=The Jerusalem Post}}</ref> On 18 January, thousands of Ukrainians marched in Kyiv and Odessa to commemorate the victims, holding signs reading ''Je Suis Volnovakha'' and ''Я Волноваха''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/europe/150119/ukraine-kyiv-je-suis-volnovakha-rally |author=Dan Peleschuk|date=19 January 2015 |title=#JeSuis … Volnovakha? |accessdate=24 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.euronews.com/2015/01/18/ukrainians-remember-13-killed-in-volnovakha |title=Ukrainians remember 13 killed in Volnovakha |work=[[EuroNews]] |date=18 January 2015|accessdate=24 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://fakty.ua/194112-v-odesse-proshla-akciya-ya---volnovaha |title=В Одессе прошла акция "Я – Волноваха" (фото) |trans-title='I am Volnovakha' rally in Odessa|author=Alexander Levit |work=[[Fakty i Kommentarii]] |date=18 January 2015 |accessdate=24 January 2015}}</ref>
[[French far-right]] activists, including [[Generation Identity]] and [[National Front (France)|National Front]] MEP [[Jean-Marie Le Pen]], adopted the slogan "Je suis [[Charles Martel|Charlie Martel]]", in reference to the Frankish king who defeated an Islamic [[Battle of Poitiers (732)|invasion in 732 AD]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Provost|first1=Lauren|title=Jean-Marie Le Pen appelle à voter Front National et déclare "Je suis Charlie Martel" après l'attentat de Charlie Hebdo|trans-title=Jean-Marie Le Pen calls voters to the National Front and declares "I am Charlie Martel"|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.fr/2015/01/09/jean-marie-le-pen-front-national-charlie-martel-hebdo-tweet-declarations_n_6443248.html|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=9 January 2015|language=French}}</ref>
[[Roger Cukierman]], president of [[Conseil Représentatif des Institutions juives de France|CRIF]], a Jewish umbrella organisation in France, spoke against supporters of the ''Charlie Hebdo'' attackers who were using the hashtag "#IamKouachi" on social media, which he called "an apology for murder."<ref>{{cite news|title=Paris anti-terror rally: all religions, ages and nations in massive show of unity|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/11/paris-france-anti-terror-rally-massive-show-unity|accessdate=12 January 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=11 January 2015}}</ref>
French comedian [[Dieudonné M'bala M'bala]] was arrested the week after the shootings after stating on Facebook that: "Tonight, as far as I'm concerned, I feel like Charlie Coulibaly", which, according to ''[[The Guardian]]'', "[mixed] the slogan 'Je suis Charlie' ... with a reference to gunman [[Amedy Coulibaly]]".<ref>{{cite news|title=Dieudonné arrested over Facebook post on Paris gunman|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/14/dieudonne-arrest-facebook-post-charlie-coulibaly-paris-gunman|accessdate=14 January 2015|work=The Guardian|date=14 January 2015}}</ref>
British [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] MP [[David Ward (British politician)|David Ward]], known for his opposition to Israel, tweeted "Je suis Palestinian" while watching the Republican marches, which together with other comments drew condemnation from his party leader, Deputy Prime Minister [[Nick Clegg]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Nick Clegg calls Lib Dem MP Paris attack tweet 'stupid'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leeds-30826637|accessdate=15 January 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=15 January 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Je suis Orlando.jpg|thumb|Variation on Je suis Charlie in support of the [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting]] victims.]] On 16 January 2015, protests against the continued creation of cartoons depicting Muhammad turned violent in several countries, including [[Algeria]], [[Nigeria]] and [[Pakistan]]. Protesters shouted "I am not Charlie, I am Muhammad" and President of [[Turkey]] [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] stated that the cartoons had nothing to do with freedom of expression, but rather with "terrorising the freedom of others." In the city of [[Zinder, Niger|Zinder]], 4 died and 45 were wounded battling police.<ref name="protests">{{Cite news |url=http://www.euronews.com/2015/01/16/anti-charlie-protests-turn-violent-in-niger-pakistan-and-algeria/|title=Anti-Charlie protests turn violent in Niger, Pakistan and Algeria |work=[[Euronews]] |date=16 January 2015 |accessdate=18 January 2015}}</ref>
In response to the issue of ''Charlie Hebdo'' following the shooting ([[Charlie Hebdo issue No. 1178|''Charlie Hebdo'' issue No. 1178]]), a number of protests in Somalia and Pakistan, some of which used "{{Lang|fr|Je suis Muslim}}" (and "j'aime mon Prophete") slogans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2914532/Anti-Charlie-Hedbo-protests-Somalia-Pakistan.html|title=Anti-Charlie Hedbo protests in Somalia and Pakistan – Daily Mail Online|work=Daily Mail}}</ref> A similar use of the slogan was made in Sydney, Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/australasia/je-suis-muslim-hundreds-rally-in-australia-over-portrayal-of-islam-and-prophet-mohamed-10000257.html|title='Je suis Muslim': Hundreds rally in Australia over portrayal of Islam and Prophet Mohamed|work=The Independent}}</ref>
In response to the apparent murder of prosecutor [[Alberto Nisman]] in Argentina in January 2015 protesters used "#Yo soy Nisman" and "Je suis Nisman" as slogans, while in response to the [[Assassination of Boris Nemtsov|assassination]] of Russian politician [[Boris Nemtsov]] in February 2015, placards saying "Je suis Boris Nemtsov" were held up during the protest march in Moscow.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Peter|title=Boris Nemtsov: marchers in Moscow honour murdered opposition politician – live updates|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2015/mar/01/boris-nemtsov-marchers-moscow-honour-murdered-opposition-politician-live-updates|accessdate=1 March 2015|work=The Guardian|date=1 March 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Je suis Paris.jpg|thumb|]] After the 13 [[November 2015 Paris attacks]], the slogan and layout was adopted and widely reused as "'''Je suis Paris'''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.directmatin.fr/france/2015-11-14/attentats-de-paris-apres-jesuischarlie-jesuisparis-715779|title=Attentats de Paris : après #JesuisCharlie, #JesuisParis|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/attaques-a-paris/article/2015/11/14/en-italie-je-suis-paris-a-la-une-d-un-journal_4809900_4809495.html|title=En Italie, "Je suis Paris" à la "une" d'un journal|first=Philippe|last=Ridet|date=14 November 2015|publisher=|via=Le Monde}}</ref>
After [[2015 Saint-Denis raid|a police raid in Saint-Denis]] that killed Paris attacks mastermind [[Abdelhamid Abaaoud]], the hashtags #JeSuisDiesel and #JeSuisChien (I am dog) were used in tribute to [[Diesel (dog)|Diesel]], a police dog who died in the raid.<ref name="DT">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/12009483/Russia-sends-police-puppy-to-France-to-replace-Diesel.html|title=Russia sends police puppy to France to replace Diesel|date= 21 November 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/trending/je-suis-chien-diesel-dog-1.3324856? Trending People use #JeSuisChien to honour police dog killed in Paris raid] CBC news, 18 November 2015</ref>
The hashtag #JeSuisDaphne was used on the Maltese social media following the murder of the journalist and blogger [[Daphne Caruana Galizia]] in October 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=Thousands mourn Caruana Galizia at Sliema vigil|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20171016/local/thousands-mourn-caruana-galizia-at-sliema-vigil.660586|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=16 October 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171016193525/https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20171016/local/thousands-mourn-caruana-galizia-at-sliema-vigil.660586|archivedate=16 October 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Translations== ''Charlie Hebdo'' staff hastily created a [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] of seven translations of ''Je suis Charlie'' which they made available on their website shortly after it returned to service. The pages appear to be scans of laser printed output, and are in a variety of fonts.
Each translation is three words, where "I am" is a single word (or "am" has been elided), "Hebdo" has been added.
# {{lang-fa|من شارلی هستم|italic=yes}} (''{{transl|fa|man Sharli hastam}}'') # {{lang-de|Ich bin Charlie}} # {{lang-es|Yo soy Charlie}} # {{Lang-sk|Som Charlie Hebdo}} # {{Lang-cs|Jsem Charlie Hebdo}} # {{lang-ar|انا شارلي|italic=yes}} (''{{transl|ar|ʾanā Sharili}}'') # {{Lang-ru|Я Шарли Эбдо|italic=yes}} (''{{transl|ru|Ya Sharli Ebdo}}'')
{{Gallery | title = The translations issued by Charlie Hebdo on the day of the shooting. | File:Je suis charlie.de.png| German | File:Je suis Charlie.es.png| Spanish | File:Je suis Charlie.ca.png| Slovak | File:Je suis Charlie.cz.png| Czech | File:Je suis Charlie.ar.png| Arabic | File:Je suis Charlie.ru.png| Russian }}
Independent translations, in Czech, for example, did not use the "Hebdo" sticking with "{{Lang|cs|Jsem Charlie}}".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parlamentnilisty.cz/arena/nazory-a-petice/Rudolf-Polanecky-Jsem-Charlie-353358|author= Názory<!--??-->|date=8 January 2015|title=Rudolf Polanecký: Jsem Charlie}}</ref>

{{Citation style|date=December 2011}} {{Infobox project | name = Ader Doutchi Maggia Rural Development Project | logo = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | commercial = No | type = Community development | location = [[Rome, Italy]] | owner = Government of Italy | founder = | mission_statement = To fight against desertification and alleviate poverty | date_of_establishment = 1983 | funding = 14,128 billion [[Italian lira|Italian Liras]] }}
The '''Ader Doutchi Maggia Rural Development Project''' (PDR-ADM), better known as '''Keita Project''', is a development project in [[Keita Department]] in central [[Niger]]. The Project has taken place in four phases, the first starting in 1983 and the most recent beginning in 2003. It was run initially by the [[Italy|Italian]] government's [[Italian Development and Cooperation Bureau]], as part of its 'Italian Initiative for the Sahel', with significant help from the [[United Nations]]. The fourth phase is being run by the [[UNDP]]. As of September 2009, the Project has cost approximately US$88 million, with the majority of funding (US$66 million) coming from the Italian government.
The main objectives of the Keita Project are to increase [[food security]] and reverse [[desertification]] in the Ader, Doutchi and Maggia valleys of Keita Department, an area which faced environmental collapse from the 1970s; a secondary objective is to thereby to reduce the high rate of [[Human migration|migration]] from this region to Italy. The methods used have included [[reforestation]] and [[land reclamation]], building new infrastructure, setting up peasants' associations, and providing technical and financial assistance.<ref>FAO (1995), The Keita Integrated Rural Development Project. FAO, [[Rome|Rome, Italy]], pp. 39.</ref> The results have been to stop and reverse falls in [[crop yield]]s and livestock numbers, to cover large areas of marginal land with forest and productive farmland, and to provide new sources of income from the land. However, desertification has continued to some degree and food security has not been fully achieved due to very high [[population growth]].
Because of the large area covered, its duration of three decades and the large amount of data collected, the Keita Project has been the subject of considerable study.<ref>http://www.case.ibimet.cnr.it/keita-niger/keita.php?page=87&action=D&fnc=browse</ref>
==Background== By the early 1980s Keita Department had suffered considerable loss of forest and agricultural land to the Sahara desert.
==Objectives== {{Empty section|date = April 2013}}
==Phases== * 1983: A plan is written for the Project * 1984: First phase of the Project begins * 2007: A new initiative (Fond Local de Développement de l’Ader Doutchi Maggia, FLD-ADM) starts with the objective of completing existing interventions, funding local investments and transferring the management and property to local institutions and organizations.
==Techniques== The PDR-ADM operated in: ''reclamation of plateaux and abandoned lands in the valleys for agricultural and pastoral purposes'', ''reforestation of slopes, of the koris banks and dunes'', ''creation of wind breaks and forest areas'', ''control of the water flow in the koris by banks consolidation and small dams''.
Simultaneously, the Project has also addressed the social and [[economic development]] by building schools, medical centers, wells and roads, and providing technical assistance and financial support for the creation of new economic activities.
The main interventions of PDR-ADM from 1984 to 2008 are shown in the table below (MAE – DGCS, 2008):
'''(Table) PDR-ADM interventions until 2008''' {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! '''INTERVENTIONS''' ! '''NOTES''' |- | ''Reclamation and Improvement of Agricultural and Pasture Lands, Reforestation and Dune Fixation'' | 34,483 HA |- | ''Trees Planted'' | 20,000,000 |- | ''Road Construction'' | 316 km |- | ''Drilled Wells'' | 4 |- | ''Small Dams'' | 43 |- | ''Dams'' | 2 |- | ''Weirs'' | 288 |- | ''Rural Buildings'' | 28,000 M<sup>2</sup> |- |}
==Environmental monitoring== * 1995-1997: the Projet d’Evaluation des Interventions de Conservation et de Récupération de l’Environnement (PEICRE) - Italian Cooperation – builds an [[Information system|Information System]] on Keita in order to evaluate and to monitor the interventions. * 1997: Keita is identified by ROSELT [http://www.oss-online.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=229&Itemid=368] (Réseau d’Observatoires et de Surveillance Ecologique à Long Terme) as one of the priority places in Niger for desertification monitoring. * 1999-2000: realization of an Information System to Sustain Evaluation Analysis and Planning; FAO-Italian Cooperation-CeSIA. * 2001: launching of Keita Observatory through the Projet d'Appui à la Formation et d'Assistance en Gestion de l’Environnement (PAFAGE)[http://www.case.ibimet.cnr.it/pafage/index.php] financed by Italian Cooperation [https://web.archive.org/web/20081220224037/http://www.cooperazioneallosviluppo.esteri.it/pdgcs/]. * 2002: IBIMET-CNR studies in the context of three United Nation major conventions (UNCCD-UNCBD-UNFCCC), about Keita potentiality in the [[Carbon dioxide sink|carbon sequestration]] [http://www.case.ibimet.cnr.it/keita-niger/data/file/keita_brochure.pdf]. * 2006: Launching of KeitaLAB [http://www.case.ibimet.cnr.it/keita-niger/index.php] by IBIMET-CNR [http://www.ibimet.cnr.it], FCS and Politecnico di Torino [http://www2.polito.it/ricerca/cctm/] in collaboration with the PDL-ADM.
Even if the PDR-ADM focused on land management, it has not deeply considered environmental monitoring. Consequently, since 1995, many initiatives have been conceived and begun to address this monitoring deficit. CASE-Ibimet [http://www.case.ibimet.cnr.it] institutions have been involved in Keita for 10 years. Keita has been chosen as a privileged environment in the drylands in order to answer to [[open problem]]s in the [[Scientific method|scientific research]] and [[International development|development cooperation]] fields: * Are climatic changes definitive or are they the expression of cyclic phenomena? * What kind of pressure can [[natural resource]]s sustain in these areas? How and in how much time could the pressure be modified? * What kind of new relationships could be created between man, the economy and the environment in the future? * Which kinds of techniques are the most appropriate for recovering degraded environmental resources and to preserve those at risk? * How can this recovery be achieved in an efficient and economically profitable way ? What are the sustainability guarantees of these interventions? * How to research a veritable partnership in the delivery of rural development programs?
==Impact== The impact of PDR-ADM interventions on the environment has been monitored by a multi- temporal analysis of land cover. Changes in land cover are the result of synergies of different factors (climate changes, interventions of PDR-ADM and demographic pressure). The environmental status before the beginning of the project testifies the negative impact of climate and anthropic pressure on the ecosystems. In 1962, the slopes of the highlands were forested but in 1972 some signs of degradation started to be evident until 1984 when the forest completely disappeared. Between 1984 and 2002, a progressive recovery of the natural vegetation has appeared <ref>Di Vecchia A., Pini G., Sorani F., Tarchiani V., Keita, Niger: the impact on environment and livelihood of 20 years fight against desertification , pp. 16 [http://www2.polito.it/ricerca/cctm/wp/WP26.pdf].</ref>
Approximately, the diachronic land cover study shows that between 1984 and 2002 woodlands increased more than 300% (10.000 ha in 1984 to 45.000 ha in 2002) against a reduction in the shrubby steppes of the 30%. This tendency is supported, besides the PDR-ADM intervention, also by the progressive increase of rainfall, which was recorded as from the years '90.
Even if the same dynamics are observed in the entire Sahelian part of Niger, this trend has only reached such results in Keita, because of the PDR-ADM intervention and the control of the human pressure on natural resources. In addition to wooden natural vegetation recovery, there has also been an evident increase of agricultural surfaces (about 80%) resulting of the substitution of large grassland areas (decreased about 70%) and of PDR-ADM [[land reclamation]] interventions (about 12.000 ha). These data confirms that the tendency of natural vegetation recolonisation is reduced by the increase of the human pressure.
Particularly, valley and glacis are exposed to higher agriculture pressure and the trend is to the extensification of croplands. This happens in three ways: the first one, by restoration of degraded lands; the second is by reclamation of grasslands and the last one by clearing of woody vegetation. The first method, supported by the PDR-ADM, concerns the slopes of the Keita valley and also the sandy dunes of the eastern plateaux. Land reclamation of grasslands has been pushed by demographic pressure especially in the Keita and Insafari valleys. Woody vegetation clearing happens especially in the secondary valleys where demographic pressure was low before 1984 and strongly increased later. On the other hand, woody vegetation restoration interests large areas on the slopes and also in the valleys as gallery forests. This trend on the slopes is particularly interesting where it is not directly due to Project interventions (plantation in trenches), because it shows the effectiveness of the watershed approach and the [[water management]] on plateaux and slopes.
Croplands degradation is also observed, due mostly to [[Eolian processes|wind erosion]] and sand accumulation. It gives evidence to the fact desertification is still active even if PDR-ADM interventions reduced its effects. In this context, the territory monitoring in the aspects that could indicate a reactivation of the desertification is very important, especially in this phase where the environment is slowly recovering equilibrium.
===Improvement of land productivity=== The pressure derived from the population growth is nowadays one of the main desertification factors, as consequence the classic environmental approach to fight desertification is doomed to fail if it is not joined with actions aimed to reduce the pressure through the creation and diversification of sources of income for the population. The productivity is assessed considering the main products contributing to population livelihood: agriculture, forestry, and livestock. Regarding agriculture, only rain-fed cereals have been considered. Concerning plantations, only the bloc ones as tranchées and banquettes are analysed.
In 2003 the whole project area produced about 40.000 tons of wood compared to 1984 production of about 17.000 tons, with a variation of 133%. The availability of leaf biomass is also increased, about of 57%.
In 1984, cereals production was about 39.000 tons while in 2003 it reached 55.000 tons . Vis-à-vis with these variations, the pressure on the natural resources also strongly increased generally more than productions, as demonstrate by population and livestock growth about 50% during the period.
