The '''Pledge to America''' is a list of proposed legislative items that the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] promised to pursue in the [[112th Congress]] if Republicans gained a majority of the seats in the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] in the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 2010|November 2010 election]].<ref name=WaPo>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/22/AR2010092206096.html |title=Highlights of House Republicans' 'Pledge to America' |date=2010-09-22 |accessdate=2010-09-22 |work=The Washington Post}}</ref> The Pledge to America was written by Rep. [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]]'s staffer Brian Wild at the behest of House Republican leaders.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=130080818 |title=Republican Kevin McCarthy On The Party's 'Pledge' |date=2010-09-23 |accessdate=2010-09-25}}</ref> The Pledge to America was publicly released on September 23, 2010, at a hardware store in [[Sterling, Virginia]].<ref name="MSNBC">{{Cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39324896/ns/politics-decision_2010/ |title=GOP 'Pledge' makes closing argument to voters |accessdate=3910-09-23 |last= |first= |date= |work= |publisher=[[MSNBC]]}}</ref>
==Main points==
The pledge criticized the [[Obama administration]], stating that "An arrogant and out-of-touch government of self-appointed elites makes decisions, issues mandates, and enacts laws without accepting or requesting the input of the many". It lists a number of issues, along with the Republican plan to solve them.
In the pledge, Republicans call for:
* Extending the temporary tax cuts passed under President [[George W. Bush]] in [[Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001|2001]] and [[Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003|2003]] for all taxpayers, including those for those earning over $200,000 ($250,000 for married couples). * A [[tax deduction]] for small businesses on up to 20 percent of their business income. * A hold on all unspent funds authorized as part of 2009's [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009|stimulus bill]] or the 2008 [[Troubled Asset Relief Program|TARP legislation]]. * Roll back government spending to 2008 levels, to save $100 billion while exempting "seniors, veterans, and our troops" from cuts; this would entail cutting 21 percent of the $477 billion budgeted for domestic discretionary spending.<ref>{{Cite web| last = O'Connor | first = Patrick | title = Republican Pledge to Cut $100 Billion May Hit Education, Cancer Research| publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.]]| date = October 1, 2010| url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-10-01/republican-pledge-on-spending-freeze-would-slash-budget-by-100-billion.html| accessdate = 2010-10-05}}</ref> * A hiring freeze on all federal agencies except those necessary to national security. * A repeal of the 2010 [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|health-care reform bill]]. * [[Tort reform|Reform of medical liability]] and health insurance practices. * A permanent ban on any federal funding for [[abortion]]. * A requirement that Congress post all bills online three days before a vote. * A requirement that lawmakers cite the specific [[United States Constitution|constitutional]] authority that enables the legislation. * A ban on trials on U.S. soil for detainees currently held at [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp|Guantanamo Bay]].
==Reactions== {{Expand section|date=September 2010}} The pledge has generally received support from Republicans.<ref name="MSNBC"/> [[National Review]] called it bolder than the [[Contract with America]] and a "shrewd political document."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/247475/we-ll-take-pledge-editors |title=We'll Take the Pledge |accessdate=2010-09-24 |date=2010-09-24}}</ref> Political strategist and former President [[George W. Bush]] adviser [[Karl Rove]] called it "important" and "practical."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703860104575507831916397878 |title=Democrats Run From Pelosi |publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=2010-09-24 | date=2010-09-23 |first=Karl |last=Rove}}</ref> Conservative radio talk show host [[Rush Limbaugh]] defended the Pledge to America, arguing, "There's nothing crazy about any of this."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rushlimbaugh.com/home/daily/site_092310/content/01125108.guest.html |title=Nothing Crazy in the GOP Pledge |accessdate=2010-09-25 |date=2010-09-23}}</ref>
Some conservative commentators, however, were critical. [[Erick Erickson]], managing editor of [[Redstate]].com called it "perhaps the most ridiculous thing to come out of Washington since [[George B. McClellan|George McClellan]]."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/24/us/politics/24repubs.html?_r=1&nl=us |title=Republicans Offer Their Agenda for Midterm Elections |accessdate=2010-09-23 |last= |first= |author=Michael D. Shear and David M. Herszenhorn |date=2010-09-23 |work= |publisher=[[New York Times]]}}</ref> Republican-affiliated columnist [[David Frum]] interpreted the document as "a GOP pledge to do nothing."<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.frumforum.com/a-gop-pledge-to-do-nothing |title=A GOP pledge to do nothing |accessdate=2010-09-24 |date=2010-09-23 }}</ref> Some social conservatives, such as [[Family Research Council]] president [[Tony Perkins (politician)|Tony Perkins]] and [[Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission|Southern Baptist Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission]] president [[Richard Land]], believed the document could have made a stronger commitment to moral issues.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2010/septemberweb-only/48-51.0.html |title=What Does the GOP Value? |author=Tobin Grant| accessdate=2010-09-26 |date=2010-09-24 }}</ref>
Democrats<ref name="MSNBC"/> and ''[[The Daily Show]]'''s [[Jon Stewart]]<ref name="Stewart">{{cite web | url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/watch/thu-september-23-2010/postcards-from-the-pledge | title=Postcards from the Pledge | accessdate=2010-09-25 |last= |first= |date= 23 Sep 2010 |work= |publisher= }}</ref> have criticized the proposals as recycled ideas from the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]]. Economist [[Paul Krugman]] criticized the document for denouncing deficits but calling for tax cuts (which he notes would add $3.7 trillion over the first ten years after its enactment) without specific spending cuts: "In essence, what [the Republicans] say is, 'Deficits are a terrible thing. Let's make them much bigger.'"<ref name="downhill">{{Citation| last = Krugman| first = Paul| author-link = Paul Krugman | title = Downhill With the G.O.P.| newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | pages = A29| date = September 24, 2010| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/24/opinion/24krugman.html?_r=1| accessdate = 2010-09-26}}</ref> Other commentators agreed that "the numbers don't remotely add up"<ref>{{Citation| last = Robinson| first = Eugene| author-link = Eugene Robinson (journalist)| title = The GOP's Hooey to America| newspaper = [[The Washington Post]]| date = September 24, 2010| url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/23/AR2010092304742.html| accessdate = 2010-09-27}}</ref> and that the Pledge "should be read as a plan to explode debt through the ceiling."<ref>{{Citation| last = Chait| first = Jonathan| author-link = Jonathan Chait| title = The Pledge To America: Deja Vu All Over Again| newspaper = [[The New Republic]]| date = September 23, 2010| url = http://www.tnr.com/blog/jonathan-chait/77894/the-pledge-america-deja-vu-all-over-again| accessdate =2010-09-27 }}</ref> Keith Boykin cited a lack of ethnic diversity in the photographs accompanying the Pledge to America, calling it a pledge "to White America."<ref name="KeithBoykin">{{cite web | url = http://thedailyvoice.com/voice/2010/09/the-gops-pledge-to-white-ameri-1-002650.php| title= The GOP's Pledge to White America | accessdate= 26 Sep 2010 |last= |first= |date= 25 Sep 2010 |work= |publisher= }}</ref>
In a ''[[Washington Post]]'' editorial, pollster [[Frank Luntz]], who polled Republican proposals in 1994 before Republicans drafted the Contract with America, found the Pledge to America more partisan-oriented, more anti-government, and lacked a "detailed course of action," but concluded it was a justifiable effort.<ref>{{Citation| last = Luntz| first = Frank I.| title = Is the 'Pledge to America' a worthy successor to the 'Contract With America'? | newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] | date = September 26, 2010| url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/24/AR2010092402436.html | accessdate = 2010-09-26}}</ref>
==Fundraising and electoral results== The Republicans' campaign tactics were effective, as Boehner's handpicked [[National Republican Congressional Committee]] chairman [[Pete Sessions]] encouraged incumbents to raise money themselves rather than relying upon the NRCC for funding.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]], one of the founders of the [[National Republican Congressional Committee#Young Guns Program|Young Guns Program]], had also implemented strategies used by former [[Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee]] chairman [[Rahm Emanuel]] back in 2006, such as aggressively recruiting Republican candidates to challenge Democrats in districts considered safe<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/25/us/politics/25campaign.html | work=The New York Times | first1=Jeff | last1=Zeleny | first2=Adam | last2=Nagourney | title=Democrats' Long-Held Seats Face G.O.P. Threat | date=2010-04-24}}</ref> and running ads attacking incumbent Democrats before the campaign began to weaken or persuade them to retire.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704141104575588631233481588?mod=googlenews_wsj | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Gerald F. | last=Seib | title=How the Rout Was Won: Careful Plans, Timely Wave | date=2010-11-03}}</ref><ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/04/us/politics/04campaign.html | work=The New York Times | first1=Jim | last1=Rutenberg | first2=Jeff | last2=Zeleny | title=Republican Game Plan Led to Historic Victory | date=2010-11-03}}</ref>
The Republicans made a net gain of 63 seats from Democrats and retook control of the chamber which they lost in the 2006 midterm elections. This number is the highest of any House victory for a single party since [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1948|1948]], and the highest of any midterm election since [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1938|1938]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.nationaljournal.com/gop-projected-to-take-over-house-20101102|title=Boehner Must Navigate Around Senate, Obama -- And Tea Party|publisher=nationaljournal.com|date=11-03-2010|accessdate=2010-11-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101104210009/http://nationaljournal.com/gop-projected-to-take-over-house-20101102|archivedate=2010-11-04|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationaljournal.com/columns/political-connections/a-heartland-headache-for-dems-20101104|title=Heartland Headache: Democrats have to be more competitive in states that don’t touch an ocean if they want to bounce back.|publisher=nationaljournal.com|date=2010-11-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125102409/http://nationaljournal.com/columns/political-connections/a-heartland-headache-for-dems-20101104|archivedate=2010-11-25|df=}}</ref>
Several powerful Democrats were defeated, including several who were chairman of standing committees, including [[Ike Skelton]] of the [[House Armed Services Committee]], [[John Spratt]] of the [[House Budget Committee]], and [[James Oberstar]] of the [[United States House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure|House Transportation Committee]]. Other congressional veterans including [[Paul Kanjorski]], [[Chet Edwards]], and [[Earl Pomeroy]] were also not returned to Congress.<ref name="Hananel">{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/11/03/AR2010110304970.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Sam | last=Hananel | title=Democratic heavy hitters go down in House | date=2010-11-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/washington/articles/2010/11/04/three_top_committee_chairmen_are_ousted/?rss_id=Boston.com+--+Top+political+stories | work=The Boston Globe | first=Sam | last=Hananel | title=Three top committee chairmen are ousted | date=2010-11-04}}</ref> [[House Appropriations Committee]] chairman [[David Obey]] had dropped out of his re-election race.<ref name="nytimes.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0510/36812.html|title=Obey won't seek reelection|publisher=|accessdate=19 July 2018}}</ref>
==Legislative results== {{As of|2014|September}} none of the items in the pledge have been enacted into law.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/dec/22/john-boehner-house-republicans-break-pledge-to-ame/|title=John Boehner, House Republicans break ‘Pledge to America,’ allow rushed legislation|last=http://www.washingtontimes.com|first=The Washington Times|newspaper=The Washington Times|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref> The website for the Pledge for America (pledge.gop.gov) has removed all mention of the pledge from the site's home page.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140918192606/http://pledge.gop.gov/|title=gop.gov - The United States House of Representatives Republican Conference|date=18 September 2014|publisher=|accessdate=19 July 2018}}</ref>
==See also== *[[United States elections, 2006#Six-point plan|Six for 06 agenda]] *[[United States House of Representatives elections, 2010]]
==References== {{Reflist|24em}}
==External links== * [https://www.gop.gov/resources/library/documents/solutions/a-pledge-to-america.pdf Official text of the pledge from House GOP site (PDF format)] * [http://pledge.gop.gov/ Pledge to America Official gop.gov site] * [http://big.assets.huffingtonpost.com/ThePledge.pdf The draft version of The Pledge To America that was passed around to reporters before the official release (PDF format)] * [http://thinkprogress.org/2010/09/23/gop-pledge-earmarks/ GOP’s Lobbyist-Authored ‘Pledge To America’ Drops Prior Pledge To Impose Earmarks Moratorium] * [http://factcheck.org/2010/09/factchecking-the-pledge/ Fact check of the Pledge to America] * [http://www.opensecrets.org/politicians/industries.php?cycle=2010&cid=N00028152&type=I Top 20 Industries contributing to Campaign Committee For Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R-CA)]

{{Redirect|The Public Eye}} {{One source|date=November 2010}} {{Infobox organization | name = Political Research Associates | logo = Political Research Associates (logo).png | type = [[non-profit organization]] | founded_date = {{start date and age|1981}} (as Midwest Research, Chicago)
{{start date|1987}} (as PRA) | founder = Dr. Jean V. Hardisty | location = [[Somerville, Massachusetts]], U.S. | origins = | key_people = [[Chip Berlet]], [[Jean Hardisty]] Tarso Luís Ramos, Pam Chamberlain, Surina Khan | area_served = Worldwide | focus = Studying the [[United States|U.S.]] [[Right wing politics|political right]] | method = | revenue = $700,000 | endowment = | num_volunteers = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = | tax_exempt = yes | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Political Research Associates''' ('''PRA''') (formerly Midwest Research, Chicago, 1981–1987), named and known on the [[World Wide Web|Web]] as '''PoliticalResearch.org''', is a non-profit research group located in [[Somerville, Massachusetts]]. ==Mission== PRA studies the [[United States|U.S.]] political [[Right-wing politics|right wing]], as well as [[White supremacy|white supremacists]], and [[paramilitary]] organizations. It has a full-time staff of six. The Executive Director is Tarso Luis Ramos. [[Jean Hardisty|Dr. Jean V. Hardisty]] was the founder and director from 1981 to 2004. [[Chip Berlet]] was the group's senior analyst from 1981–2011. Other staff members include Eric Ethington (Communications Director), Gabriel Joffe (Program Coordinator), and Kassia Palys (Development Coordinator). Staff researchers include Rev. [[Kapya Kaoma]], Cole Parke, and Mariya Strauss. Fellows include [[Frederick Clarkson]], Rachel Tabachnick, T.F. Charlton, and Spencer Sunshine. PRA publishes a journal, ''The Public Eye'', quarterly, which reports on specific and current movements or trends within the U.S. political Right, and also produces special reports, past examples of which include "Calculated Compassion: How the Ex-Gay Movement Serves the Right's Attacks on Democracy,"{{cite web|last=Khan|first=Surina|title=Calculated Compassion|url=http://www.publiceye.org/equality/x-gay/Calculated_Compassion_TOC.html|publisher=Political Research Associates|accessdate=2011}} authored by former PRA research analyst, Surina Khan," which details attacks on [[gay]]s and [[lesbian]]s, and "Decades of Distortion," which alleged [[scapegoat]]ing of welfare recipients.[http://www.publiceye.org/about.html PRA: About Us] The group provides public speakers, and has staff on hand to answer queries from journalists, researchers, and activists. Its annual funding of approximately $700,000 per year comes from foundation grants, individual contributions, and the sale of research materials. Expenditures are directed toward staffing, general & administrative expenses, programs and fundraising.[http://www.publiceye.org/aboutpra/annual_rep_2004.pdf PRA Annual Report 2003-2004] See page 16 Among its major donors are the [[Public Welfare Foundation]] and the [[Ford Foundation]]. PRA is supported by a number of [[Political progressivism|progressive]] and [[American liberalism|liberal]] activists, including Anne Braden of the [[Southern Organizing Committee]], and Suzanne Pharr of the [[Highlander Research Center]]. Pharr has written that PRA "sets the standard for researchers and political analysts of integrity," and describes the group's research as "thorough, thoughtful, carefully researched, and presented within a broad context of understanding of the complex relationships and activities of the Right." ==See also== * ''[[Clouds Blur the Rainbow]]'', 1987 report by [[Chip Berlet]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.politicalresearch.org PoliticalResearch.org] - The Website of Political Research Associates [[Category:Political science organizations]] [[Category:American journalism organizations]]

{{Karnataka History}}<!--[[Image:Keladi Rameshwara gandaberunda.JPG|right|thumb| ''[[Gandaberunda]]'' (two headed bird), emblem of Karnataka]]-->
The '''political history of medieval Karnataka''' spans the 4th to the 16th centuries, when the empires that evolved in the [[Karnataka]] region of [[India]] made a lasting impact on the subcontinent. Before this, alien empires held sway over the region, and the nucleus of power was outside modern Karnataka. The medieval era can be broadly divided into several periods: The earliest native kingdoms and imperialism; the successful domination of the Gangetic plains in northern India and rivalry with the empires of [[Ancient Tamil country|Tamilakam]] over the [[Vengi]] region; and the domination of the southern Deccan and consolidation against Muslim invasion. The origins of the rise of the Karnataka region as an independent power date back to the fourth-century birth of the [[Kadamba Dynasty]] of [[Banavasi]], the earliest of the native rulers to conduct administration in the native language of [[Kannada]] in addition to the official [[Sanskrit]]. This is the historical starting point in studying the development of the region as an enduring geopolitical entity and of Kannada as an important regional language.
In the southern regions of Karnataka, the [[Western Ganga Dynasty|Western Gangas]] of [[Talakad]] were contemporaries of the Kadambas. The Kadambas and Gangas were followed by the imperial dynasties of the [[Badami Chalukya Empire]], the [[Rashtrakuta Empire]], the [[Western Chalukya Empire]], the [[Hoysala Empire]] and the [[Vijayanagara Empire]], all patronising the ancient Indic religions while showing tolerance to the new cultures arriving from the west of the subcontinent. The Muslim invasion of the Deccan resulted in the breaking away of the feudatory Sultanates in the 14th century. The rule of the [[Bahamani Sultanate]] of [[Bidar]] and the [[Bijapur Sultanate]] from the northern Deccan region caused a mingling of the ancient Hindu traditions with the nascent Islamic culture in the region. The hereditary ruling families and clans ably served the large empires and upheld the local culture and traditions. The fall of the Vijayanagara Empire in 1565 brought about a slow disintegration of Kannada-speaking regions into minor kingdoms that struggled to maintain autonomy in an age dominated by foreigners until unification and independence in 1947.
==Kadambas and Gangas== {{See also|Kadamba Dynasty|Western Ganga Dynasty|Western Ganga literature}} [[Image:Doddagaddavalli Lakshmidevi temple1 retouched.JPG|thumb|left|Kadamba tower at [[Doddagaddavalli]]]] [[Image:Indian Kadamba Empire map.svg|thumb|left|[[Kadamba Dynasty|Kadamba Empire]], 500 CE.]] <!--[[Image:Gomateswara.jpg|thumb|right|[[Gomateshwara]] (982) at [[Shravanabelagola]]]]--> Prior to and during the early centuries of the first millennium, large areas of the Karnataka region was ruled by such imperial powers as the [[Mauryas]] of Maghada and later the [[Satavahanas]], empires whose centres of power were in the Gangetic plains and Central India respectively. With the weakening of the Satavahanas, the Pallavas of Kanchi took control for a brief duration.<ref name="pal">Ramesh (1984), pp1–3</ref> In the 4th century, the rise to power of the [[Kadamba Dynasty]] of [[Banavasi]] identified the Karnataka region as an independent political entity and Kannada as an administrative language from the middle of the 5th century.<ref name="first">From the Halmidi inscription (Ramesh 1984, pp10–11)</ref> The Kadambas were natives of the [[Talagunda]] region (in modern [[Shivamogga district]]) as proven by inscriptions.<ref name="first1">The Kadambas were Kanarese speaking dravidians inducted into the Brahmin fold (Moraes 1931, p11)</ref><ref name="first2">Their local tribal origins is attested by the Talagunda inscription, R.N. Nandi in Adiga (2006), p93</ref><ref name="first3">Ramesh (1984), p3</ref><ref name="naga">Some inscriptions claim the Kadambas came from a Naga descent (snake worshippers) making them natives of Karnataka region, Moraes (1931), p10</ref><ref name="naga1">Kamath (2001), p30</ref> [[Mayurasharma]], a Brahmin native of Talagunda who was humiliated by a [[Pallava]] guard, rose in rage against the Pallava control of the Banavasi region and declared his independence in 345.<ref name="tala">From the Talagunda inscription (B.L. Rice in Kamath 2001, pp 30–31)</ref><ref name="tala1">Ramesh (1984), 1984, p6</ref><ref name="tala2">Moraes (1931), p10</ref> After many wars, the Pallava king had to accept the sovereignty of the Kadambas and Mayurasharma, the founding king, crowned himself at Banavasi (in the present day [[Uttara Kannada]] district).<ref name="cor">Chopra (2003), p161, part1; Kamath (2001), p30</ref> [[Image:Western-ganga-empire-map.svg|thumb|right|[[Western Ganga Dynasty|Western Ganga Territories]], 800 CE.]] The fact that the Kadambas cultivated marital ties with the imperial [[Vakatakas]] and [[Gupta Empire|Gupta]] dynasties attests to their power.<ref name="vaka">Moraes (1931), p26</ref> [[Kakusthavarma]], the most powerful ruler of the dynasty whom inscriptions describe as "ornament of the Kadamba family" and "Sun among the kings of wide spread flame", gave one daughter in marriage to Vakataka Narendrasena and another to [[Skandagupta]], grandson of [[Chandragupta II]] of the Gupta dynasty.<ref name="marriage">From the Talagunda inscription (Moraes 1931, pp26–27)</ref><ref name="marriage1">From the Balaghat inscription of Vakataka Prithvisena (Kamath 2001, p33)</ref> Historians trace their rise to political power through the examination of the contemporaneous Sanskrit writing, ''Aichitya Vichara Charcha'' by [[Kshemendra]], which quotes portions of a writing ''Kunthalesvara Dautya'' by the famous poet [[Kalidasa]]. Here Kalidasa describes his visit to the Kadamba kingdom as an ambassador where he was not offered a seat in the court of the Kadamba king and had to sit on the ground. Historians view this act as one of assertion by the Kadambas who considered themselves equal to the imperial Gupta dynasty.<ref name="equal">Moraes, Desai and Panchamukhi in Kamath (2001), p33</ref> [[Image:Relief of Jain tirthankara in the Panchakuta Basadi at Kambadahalli.jpg|thumb|left|Roof relief sculpture, Jain Panchakuta basadi at [[Kambadahalli]].]] Family feuds and conflicts ended the Kadamba rule in the middle of the 6th century when the last Kadamba ruler Krishna Varma II was subdued by [[Pulakeshin I]] of the Chalukya feudatory, ending their sovereign rule. The Kadambas would continue to rule parts of Karnataka and Goa for many centuries to come but never again as an independent kingdom.<ref name="sov">Chopra (2003), p162, part1; Kamath (2001), p35</ref> Some historians view the Kadambas as the originators of the Karnataka architectural tradition although there were elements in common with the structures built by the contemporaneous Pallavas of Kanchi.<ref name="tradition">Moraes in Kamath (2001), p37</ref> The oldest surviving Kadamba structure is one dating to the late 5th century in [[Halsi]] in modern [[Belgaum district]]. The most prominent feature of their architectural style, one that remained popular centuries later and was used by the Hoysalas and the Vijayanagar kings, is the ''Kadamba Shikara'' (Kadamba tower) with a ''Kalasa'' (pot) on top.<ref name="kalasa">Kamath (2001), p38</ref>
The [[Western Ganga Dynasty]], contemporaries of the Kadambas, came to power from [[Kolar]] but in the late 4th century - early 5th century moved their capital to [[Talakad]] in modern [[Mysore district]].<ref name="my">Chopra (2003), p159, part1; Kamath (2001), p40</ref> They ruled the region historically known as Gangavadi comprising most of the modern southern districts of Karnataka. Acting as a buffer state between the [[Kannada]] kingdoms of Karnataka region and the Tamil kingdoms of [[Ancient Tamil country|Tamilakam]], the Western Ganga architectural innovations show mixed influences.<ref name="mixed">The impact of the Pallava, early Chalukya and a distinct [[Jain]] influence added to their own innovations are the main features of their architectural idiom (Reddy, Sharma and Rao in Kamath 2001, p50)</ref> Their sovereign rule ended around the same time as the Kadambas when they came under the Badami Chalukya control. The Western Gangas continued to rule as a feudatory till the beginning of the eleventh century when they were defeated by the [[Cholas]] of [[Tanjavur]].<ref name="tanjore">Chopra (2003), p160, part1</ref> Important figures among the Gangas were King [[Durvinita]] and [[Shivamara II]], admired as able warriors and scholars,<ref name="durva">Narasimhacharya (1988), p2</ref> and minister [[Chavundaraya]] who was a builder, a warrior and a writer in Kannada and Sanskrit.<ref name="chavunda">Narasimhacharya (1988), p18</ref><ref name="war">Chopra (2003), pp159–160, part1; Kamath (2001), p50</ref> The most important architectural contributions of these Gangas are the monuments and [[basadi]]s of [[Shravanabelagola]], the [[monolith]] of [[Gomateshwara]] termed as the mightiest achievement in the field of sculpture in ancient Karnataka and the ''Panchakuta'' basadi ( five towers) at [[Kambadahalli]].<ref name="contri">Kamath (2001), pp51–52</ref> Their free standing pillars (called ''Mahasthambhas'' and ''Brahmasthambhas'') and [[Hero stone]]s (''virgal'') with sculptural detail are also considered a unique contribution.<ref name="maha">Fergusson in Kamath (2001), p52</ref>
==Badami Chalukyas== <!--[[Image:Chalukya territories lg.png|thumb|right|Badami Chalukya territories in the reign of [[Pulakeshin II]], 640]]--> [[Image:badami-chalukya-empire-map.svg|thumb|right|[[Chalukya dynasty|Badami Chalukya Empire]] during the reign of [[Pulakeshin II]], 640 CE.]] <!--[[Image:Pattadakal Virupaksha temple.jpg|thumb|right|Virupaksha Temple at Pattadakal]]--> {{See also|Chalukya dynasty|Badami Chalukya Architecture}}
The [[Chalukya dynasty]], natives of the [[Aihole]] and [[Badami]] region in Karnataka, were at first a feudatory of the Kadambas.<ref name="natives">N. Laxminarayana Rao and S. C. Nandinath in Kamath 2001, p57</ref><ref name="natives1">Keay (2000), p168</ref> <ref name="natives2">Jayasimha and Ranaraga, ancestors of Pulakeshin I, were administrative officers in the Badami province under the Kadambas (Fleet in Kanarese Dynasties, p343), (Moraes 1931, p51)</ref><ref name="natives3">Thapar (2003), p328</ref><ref name="natives4">Quote:"They belonged to the Karnataka country and their mother tongue was Kannada" (Sen 1999, p360); Kamath (2001), p58,</ref> They encouraged the use of Kannada in addition to the Sanskrit language in their administration.<ref name="ex">Considerable number of their records are in Kannada (Kamath 2001, p67)</ref><ref name="natural">7th century Chalukya inscriptions call Kannada the natural language (Thapar 2003, p345)</ref> In the middle of the 6th century the Chalukyas came into their own when [[Pulakeshin I]] made the hill fortress in Badami his center of power.<ref name="hillfort">Sen (1999), p360</ref> During the rule of [[Pulakeshin II]] a south Indian empire sent expeditions to the north past the [[Tapti River]] and [[Narmada River]] for the first time and successfully defied Harshavardhana, the King of Northern India (''Uttarapatheswara''). The [[Aihole]] inscription of Pulakeshin II, written in classical Sanskrit language and old Kannada script dated 634,<ref name="mix">In this composition, the poet deems himself an equal to Sanskrit scholars of lore like Bharavi and Kalidasa (Sastri 1955, p312</ref><ref name="mix1">Kamath (2001), p59</ref> proclaims his victories against the Kingdoms of Kadambas, Western Gangas, [[Alupas]] of South Canara, Mauryas of [[Puri]], Kingdom of [[Dakshina Kosala|Kosala]], [[Malwa]], [[Lata (region)|Lata]] and Gurjaras of southern [[Rajasthan]]. The inscription describes how King Harsha of [[Kannauj]] lost his ''Harsha'' (joyful disposition) on seeing a large number of his war elephants die in battle against Pulakeshin II.<ref name="aihole">Keay (2000), p169</ref><ref name="gurjara">Sen (1999), pp361–362</ref><ref name="aihole1">Kamath (2001), pp59–60</ref><ref name="fear">Some of these kingdoms may have submitted out of fear of Harshavardhana of Kannauj (Majumdar in Kamat 2001, p59)</ref><ref name="fear1">The rulers of Kosala were the [[Panduvamshis of Dakshina Kosala|Panduvamshis of South Kosala]] (Sircar in Kamath 2001, pp59)</ref> [[Image:Relief of seated Vishnu at the Badami cave temple no.3.jpg|thumb|left|[[Badami Cave Temples]] No 3.(Vishnu)]] These victories earned him the title ''Dakshinapatha Prithviswamy'' (lord of the south). Pulakeshin II continued his conquests in the east where he conquered all kingdoms in his way and reached the [[Bay of Bengal]] in present-day Orissa. A Chalukya viceroyalty was set up in Gujarat and Vengi (coastal Andhra) and princes from the Badami family were dispatched to rule them. Having subdued the Pallavas of Kanchipuram, he accepted tributes from the [[Pandyas]] of [[Madurai]], [[Chola dynasty]] and [[Chera dynasty|Chera]]s of the Kerala region. Pulakeshin II thus became the master of India, south of the Narmada River.<ref name="nar">Keay (2000), p170</ref> Pulakeshin II is widely regarded as one of the great kings in Indian history.<ref name="great">Kamath (2001), pp58</ref><ref name="great1">Ramesh 1984, p76</ref> [[Hiuen-Tsiang]], a [[China|Chinese]] traveller visited the court of Pulakeshin II at this time and [[Persian Empire|Persian]] emperor [[Khosrau II]] exchanged ambassadors.<ref name="tabri">From the notes of Arab traveller Tabari (Kamath 2001, p60)</ref> However, the continuous wars with [[Pallavas]] took a turn for the worse in 642 when the Pallava king [[Narasimhavarman I]] avenged his father's defeat,<ref name="vincent">{{cite book |last = Smith |first= Vincent Arthur |title= The Early History of India |year=1904 |publisher= The Clarendon press |pages = 325–327 }}</ref> conquered and plundered the [[Vatapi|capital of Pulakeshin II]] who may have died in battle.<ref name="vincent" /><ref name="died">Sen (1999), p362</ref> A century later, Chalukya [[Vikramaditya II]] marched victoriously into [[Kanchipuram]], the Pallava capital and occupied it on three occasions, the third time under the leadership of his son and crown prince Kirtivarman II. He thus avenged the earlier humiliation of the Chalukyas by the Pallavas and engraved a [[Kannada]] inscription on the victory pillar at the Kailasanatha Temple.<ref name="kanchi">Thapar (2003), p331, p345</ref><ref name="kanchi1">Sastri (1955) p140</ref><ref name="kanchi2">Ramesh (1984), pp159–160</ref><ref name="kanchi3">Sen (1999), p364</ref> He later overran the other traditional kingdoms of Tamil country, the Pandyas, Cholas and Keralas in addition to subduing a [[Kalabhra]] ruler.<ref name="kanchi4">Ramesh (1984), p159</ref>
The [[Kappe Arabhatta]] record from this period (700) in ''tripadi'' (three line) metre is considered the earliest available record in Kannada poetics. <!--Some contemporary literary writings in Kannada now considered extinct are, ''Karnateshwara Katha'' (a eulogy of Pulakeshin II),<ref name="ex"/> ''Prabhrita'' by Syamakundacharya and ''Chudamani'' by Tumubuluracharya, both of 650 have been referenced in later centuries.<ref name="ex1">Sastri (1955), p355</ref><ref name="ex2">Narasimhacharya (1988), p4</ref>--> The most enduring legacy of the Chalukya dynasty is the architecture and art that they left behind.<ref name="legacy">Hardy (1995), p65–66</ref> More than one hundred and fifty monuments attributed to them, built between 450 and 700, have survived in the [[Malaprabha]] basin in Karnataka.<ref name="temple">Over 125 temples exist in Aihole alone, {{cite web|title=Monuments of India|url=http://www.art-and-archaeology.com/india/india.html |author=Michael D. Gunther, 2002|publisher=|work=|accessdate=2006-11-10}}</ref> The constructions are centred in a relatively small area within the Chalukyan heartland. The structural temples at [[Pattadakal]], a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]], the cave temples of [[Badami]], the temples at [[Mahakuta group of temples|Mahakuta]] and early experiments in temple building at [[Aihole]] are their most celebrated monuments.<ref name="legacy"/> Two of the famous paintings at [[Ajanta Caves|Ajanta]] cave no. 1, "The Temptation of the Buddha" and "The Persian Embassy" are also credited to them. <ref name="monuments">{{cite web|title=History of Karnataka—Chalukyas of Badami|url=http://www.ourkarnataka.com/history.htm |author=Arthikaje, Mangalore|publisher=© 1998–2000 OurKarnataka.Com, Inc|work=|accessdate=2006-11-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061104095148/http://www.ourkarnataka.com/history.htm <!--Added by H3llBot-->|archivedate=2006-11-04}}</ref> <ref name="monuments1">The Badami Chalukya introduced in the western Deccan a glorious chapter alike in heroism in battle and cultural magnificence in peace (K.V. Sounderrajan in Kamath 2001, p68</ref> Further, they influenced the architecture in far off places like Gujarat and [[Vengi]] as evidenced in the Nava Brahma temples at Alampur.<ref name="inf">Kamath (2001), p68</ref>
==Rashtrakutas== {{See also|Rashtrakuta Dynasty|Rashtrakuta literature}} [[Image:Indian Rashtrakuta Empire map.svg|thumb|right|[[Rashtrakuta|Rashtrakuta Empire]] in 800 CE, 915 CE.]] <!--[[Image:Ellora cave16 001.jpg|thumb|right|Kailasanatha Temple at [[Ellora]]]]--> In the middle of the 8th century the Chalukya rule was ended by their feudatory, the Rashtrakuta family rulers of [[Berar Sultanate|Berar]] (in present-day [[Amravati district]] of [[Maharashtra]]). Sensing an opportunity during a weak period in the Chalukya rule, [[Dantidurga]] trounced the great Chalukyan "Karnatabala" (power of Karnata).<ref name="bala">From the Rashtrakuta inscriptions (Kamath 2001, p57, p64)</ref><ref name="bala1">The Samangadh copper plate grant (753) confirms that feudatory Dantidurga defeated the Chalukyas and humbled their great ''Karnatik'' army (referring to the army of the Badami Chalukyas) (Reu 1933, p54)</ref> Having overthrown the Chalukyas, the Rashtrakutas made [[Manyakheta]] their capital (modern Malkhed in [[Gulbarga district]]).<ref name="manya">A capital which could put to shame even the capital of gods-From Karda plates (Altekar 1934, p47)</ref><ref name="manya1">A capital city built to excel that of Indra (Sastri, 1955, p4, p132, p146)</ref> Although the origins of the early Rashtrakuta ruling families in central India and the Deccan in the 6th and 7th centuries is controversial, during the eighth through the tenth centuries they emphasised the importance of the Kannada language in conjunction with Sanskrit in their administration. Rashtrakuta inscriptions are in Kannada and Sanskrit only. They encouraged literature in both languages and thus literature flowered under their rule.<ref name="earlylit1">Altekar (1934), pp411–413</ref><ref name="early1">Chopra (2003), p87, part1; Literature in Kannada and Sanskrit flowered during the Rashtrakuta rule (Kamath 2001, p73, pp 88–89)</ref><ref name="early2">Even royalty of the empire took part in poetic and literary activities (Thapar 2003, p334)</ref><ref name="patron"/><ref name="eralylit2">[[Bisheshwar Nath Reu|Reu]] (1933), pp37–38</ref> [[Image:Kailasha temple at ellora.JPG|thumb|left|[[Ellora Kailasanathar Temple|Kailash Temple]] in [[Ellora Caves]]]]
The Rashtrakutas quickly became the most powerful Deccan empire, making their initial successful forays into the [[doab]] region of [[Ganges River]] and [[Yamuna|Jamuna River]] during the rule of [[Dhruva Dharavarsha]].<ref name="dig">Chopra (2003), p89, part1; His victories were a "digvijaya" gaining only fame and booty in that region (Altekar in Kamath 2001, p75)</ref> The rule of his son [[Govinda III]] signaled a new era with Rashtrakuta victories against the [[Pala Dynasty]] of [[Bengal]] and Gurjara [[Pratihara]] of north western India resulting in the capture of [[Kannauj]]. The Rashtrakutas held Kannauj intermittently during a period of a tripartite struggle for the resources of the rich [[Gangetic plains]].<ref name="triparty">Chopra (2003), p90, part1</ref> Because of Govinda III's victories, historians have compared him to [[Alexander the Great]] and [[Pandava]] [[Arjuna]] of the Hindu epic [[Mahabharata]].<ref name="pandava">Keay (2000), p199)</ref> The Sanjan inscription states the horses of Govinda III drank the icy water of the Himalayan stream and his war elephants tasted the sacred waters of the Ganges River.<ref name="ganga">Kamath 2001, p76</ref> [[Amoghavarsha I]], eulogised by contemporary Arab traveller Sulaiman as one among the four great emperors of the world, succeeded Govinda III to the throne and ruled during an important cultural period that produced landmark writings in Kannada and Sanskrit.<ref name="loving"/><ref name="landmark">[[Kavirajamarga]] in Kannada and ''Prashnottara Ratnamalika'' in Sanskrit (Reu 1933, p38)</ref><ref name="landmark1">Kamath (2001), p90</ref> The benevolent development of Jain religion was a hallmark of his rule. Because of his religious temperament, his interest in the arts and literature and his peace-loving nature,<ref name="loving">Chopra (2003), p91, part1</ref> he has been compared to emperor [[Ashoka]].<ref name="Ashoka">Panchamukhi in Kamath (2001), p80</ref> The rule of [[Indra III]] in the tenth century enhanced the Rashtrakuta position as an imperial power as they conquered and held Kannauj again.<ref name="master">Chopra (2003), p92, part1; Altekar in Kamath 2001, p81</ref> [[Krishna III]] followed Indra III to the throne in 939. A patron of Kannada literature and a powerful warrior, his reign marked the submission of the [[Paramara]] of [[Ujjain]] in the north and Cholas in the south.<ref name="paramar">Chopra (2003), p92–93, part1</ref>
An Arabic writing ''Silsilatuttavarikh'' (851) called the Rashtrakutas one among the four principle empires of the world.<ref name="siraf">Reu (1933), p39</ref> ''Kitab-ul-Masalik-ul-Mumalik'' (912) called them the "greatest kings of India" and there were many other contemporaneous books written in their praise.<ref name="hara">''Murujul Zahab'' by Al Masudi (944), ''Kitabul Akalim'' by Al Istakhri (951), ''Ashkal-ul-Bilad'' by Ibn Haukal (976) (Reu 1933, p41–42)</ref> The Rashtrakuta empire at its peak spread from [[Cape Comorin]] in the south to Kannauj in the north and from [[Banaras]] in the east to Broach (Bharuch) in the west.<ref name="Himalayas">From the Sanjan inscriptions, {{cite web|title=The Rashrakutas|url=http://www.kamat.com/kalranga/deccan/rashtrakutas/|author=Dr. Jyotsna Kamat|publisher=1996–2006 Kamat's Potpourri|work=|accessdate=2006-12-20}}</ref> While the Rashtrakutas built many fine monuments in the Deccan, the most extensive and sumptuous of their work is the monolithic Kailasanatha temple at [[Ellora]], the temple being a splendid achievement.<ref name="sump">Keay (2000), p200</ref> In Karnataka their most famous temples are the Kashivishvanatha temple and the Jain Narayana temple at Pattadakal. All of the monuments are designated [[UNESCO World Heritage Sites]].<ref name="karnataka_whs">{{cite web|title=Reclaiming past glory|url=http://archive.deccanherald.com/deccanherald/feb272007/spectrum1437452007226.asp|author=Vijapur, Raju S.|publisher=Spectrum|work=Deccan Herald|accessdate=2007-02-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007194411/http://archive.deccanherald.com/deccanherald/feb272007/spectrum1437452007226.asp|archivedate=2011-10-07|df=}}</ref>
==Western Chalukyas== {{See also|Western Chalukya Empire|Kannada literature in the Western Chalukya Empire|Western Chalukya Architecture}} [[Image:Western-chalukya-empire-map.svg|thumb|right|[[Western Chalukya Empire]] in 1121 CE.]] <!--[[Image:Trimurthi Kedareshwara Balligavi.jpg|thumb|left|[[Trimurthi]] sculpture at [[Balligavi]]]]--> <!--[[Image:Shimoga kedareshwara temple.JPG|thumb|right|Kedareshwara temple (1060) at [[Balligavi]]]]-->
In the late 10th century, the [[Western Chalukya Empire|Western Chalukyas]], also known as the Kalyani Chalukyas or 'Later' Chalukyas rose to power by overthrowing the Rashtrakutas under whom they had been serving as feudatories. [[Manyakheta]] was their capital early on before they moved it to Kalyani (modern [[Basavakalyan]]). Whether the kings of this empire belonged to the same family line as their namesakes, the [[Badami Chalukyas]] is still debated.<ref name="bilhana1">Chopra (2003), p137, part1</ref><ref name="bilhana">Fleet, Bhandarkar and Altekar and Gopal B.R in (Kamath 2001, p100)</ref> Whatever the Western Chalukya origins, Kannada remained their language of administration and the Kannada and Sanskrit literature of their time was prolific.<ref name="patron">Narasimhacharya (1988), p68, p17–21</ref><ref name="form">Sen (1999), p. 393</ref><ref name="administrator1">Sastri (1955), pp356–358; Kamath (2001), p114</ref><ref name="administrator">More inscriptions in Kannada are attributed to the Chalukya King [[Vikramaditya VI]] than to any other king prior to the 12th century, {{cite web|title=Chalukyas of Kalyana |url=http://www.kamat.com/kalranga/deccan/deckings.htm|author=Kamat, Jyotsna|publisher=1996–2006 Kamat's Potpourri|work=|accessdate=2006-12-24}}</ref> [[Tailapa II]], a feudatory ruler from Tardavadi (modern [[Bijapur district, Karnataka|Bijapur district]]), re-established the Chalukya rule by defeating the Rashtrakutas during the reign of [[Karka II]]. He timed his rebellion to coincide with the confusion caused by the invading [[Paramara]] of Central India to the Rashtrakutas capital in 973.<ref name="central2">From the 957 and 965 records (Kamath 2001, p101)</ref><ref name="central">Sastri 1955, p162</ref><ref name="central1">Tailapa II was helped in this campaign by the Kadambas of [[Hanagal]] (Moraes 1931, pp 93–94)</ref> This era produced prolonged warfare with the Chola dynasty of [[Tamilakam]] for control of the resources of the [[Godavari River]]-[[Krishna River]] doab region in [[Vengi]]. [[Someshvara I]], a brave Chalukyan king, successfully curtailed the growth of the Chola Empire to the south of the [[Tungabhadra River]] region despite suffering some defeats<ref name="curtail">Ganguli in Kamath 2001, p103</ref><ref name="curtail1">Sastri (1955), p167–168</ref> while maintaining control over his feudatories in the Konkan, Gujarat, Malwa and [[Kalinga (historical region)|Kalinga]] regions.<ref name="curtail2">Kamath (2001), p104</ref> For approximately 100 years, beginning in the early 11th century, the Cholas occupied large areas of South Karnataka region (Gangavadi).<ref name="gangavadi">Sastri (1955), p164, p174; The Cholas occupied Gangavadi from 1004 to 1114 (Kamath 2001, p118)</ref> [[Image:Ornate pillars in the Saraswati temple at Gadag.jpg|thumb|left|Gadag style pillars, [[Western Chalukya Architecture|Western Chalukya art]].]] In 1076, the ascent of the most famous king of this Chalukya family, [[Vikramaditya VI]], changed the balance of power in favour of the Chalukyas.<ref name="balance">Chopra (2003), p139, part1</ref> His fifty-year reign was an important period in Karnataka's history and is referred to as the "Chalukya Vikrama era".<ref name="vikram">Thapar, 2003, pp 468–469</ref> His victories over the Cholas in the late 11th and early 12th centuries put an end to the Chola influence in the Vengi region permanently.<ref name="balance"/> Some of the well-known contemporaneous feudatory families of the Deccan under Chalukya control were the Hoysalas, the [[Seuna Yadavas of Devagiri]], the [[Kakatiya dynasty]] and the Southern Kalachuri.<ref name="balance" /> At their peak, the Western Chalukyas ruled a vast empire stretching from the [[Narmada River]] in the north to the [[Kaveri River]] in the south. Vikramaditya VI is considered one of the most influential kings of Indian history.<ref name="none">Poet [[Bilhana]] in his Sanskrit work wrote "Rama Rajya" regarding his rule, poet Vijnaneshwara called him "A king like none other" (Kamath 2001, p106)</ref><ref name="apponent">Sastri (1955), p6</ref> Important architectural works were created by these Chalukyas, especially in the Tungabhadra river valley, that served as a conceptual link between the building idioms of the early Badami Chalukyas and the later Hoysalas.<ref name="link">Sastri (1955), pp 427–428; Quote:"Their creations have the pride of place in Indian art tradition" (Kamath 2001, p115)</ref><ref name="link1">Quote:"Of the city of Kalyana, situated in the north of Karnataka nothing is left, but a fabulous revival in temple building during the 11th century in central Karnataka testifies to the wealth during Kalyan Chalukya rule"(Foekema (1996), p14)</ref> With the weakening of the Chalukyas in the decades following the death of Vikramaditya VI in 1126, the feudatories of the Chalukyas gained their independence.
The [[Kalachuris of Karnataka]], whose ancestors were immigrants into the southern deccan from central India, had ruled as a feudatory from Mangalavada (modern Mangalavedhe in Maharashtra).<ref name="manda">Kamath (2001), p107</ref> [[Bijjala II]], the most powerful ruler of this dynasty, was a commander (''mahamandaleswar'') during the reign of Chalukya Vikramaditya VI.<ref name="karhad">From the 1142 and 1147 records, Kamath (2001), p108</ref> Seizing an opportune moment in the waning power of the Chalukyas, Bijjala II declared independence in 1157 and annexed their capital [[Basavakalyana|Kalyani]].<ref name="chikka">Chopra (2003), p139, part1; From the Chikkalagi records (Kamath 2001, p108)</ref> His rule was cut short by his assassination in 1167 and the ensuing civil war caused by his sons fighting over the throne ended the dynasty as the last Chalukya scion regained control of Kalyani. This victory however, was short-lived as the Chalukyas were eventually driven out by the Seuna Yadavas.<ref name="regain">Chopra (2003), p140, part1; Kamath (2001) p109</ref>
==Hoysalas== {{See also|Hoysala Empire|Literature in the Hoysala Empire|Hoysala architecture}} <!--[[Image:Belur Chennakeshava temple.JPG|thumb|right|ChennakeshavaTemple at [[Belur]]]]--> [[Image:Hoysala Empire extent.svg|thumb|right|[[Hoysala Empire]] in 1200 CE.]]
The Hoysalas had become a powerful force even during their rule from [[Belur, Karnataka|Belur]] in the 11th century as a feudatory of the Chalukyas (in the south Karnataka region).<ref name="gratiate">Sen (1999), p498</ref> In the early 12th century they successfully fought the Cholas in the south, convincingly defeating them in the battle of [[Talakad]] and moved their capital to nearby [[Halebidu]].<ref name="provincial">Sen (1999), p499</ref><ref name="talkad">Vishnuvardhana made many military conquests later to be further expanded by his successors into one of the most powerful empires of South India—William Coelho. He was the true maker of the Hoysala kingdom—B.S.K. Iyengar in Kamath (2001), p124–126</ref> Historians refer to the founders of the dynasty as natives of [[Malnad]] Karnataka, based on the numerous inscriptions calling them ''Maleparolganda'' or "Lord of the Male (hills) chiefs" (''Malepas'').<ref name="gratiate"/><ref name="malnad">B.L.Rice in Kamath (2001), p123</ref><ref name="malnad1">Keay (2000), p251</ref><ref name="malnad2">Thapar (2003), p367</ref><ref name="malnad3">Kamath (2001), p123</ref><ref name="malnad4">Natives of south Karnataka (Chopra, 2003, p150 Part1)</ref> With the waning of the Western Chalukya power, the Hoysalas declared their independence in the late twelfth century. [[Image:Shilabaalika on pillar bracket in Chennakeshava Temple at Belur3.jpg|thumb|left| Shilabalika, Chennakeshava Temple, [[Belur, Karnataka|Belur]].]] During this period of Hoysala control, distinctive Kannada literary metres such as ''Ragale'' (blank verse), ''Sangatya'' (meant to be sung to the accompaniment of a musical instrument), ''Shatpadi'' (seven line) etc. became widely accepted.<ref name="patron"/><ref name="ragala10">Shiva Prakash in Ayyappapanicker (1997), pp164, 203; Rice E. P. (1921), p59</ref><ref name="sang1">Kamath (2001), pp132–134</ref><ref name="sang">Sastri (1955), p359, p361</ref> The Hoysalas expanded the [[Vesara]] architecture stemming from the Chalukyas,<ref name="cul">Sastri (1955), p427</ref> culminating in the Hoysala architectural articulation and style as exemplified in the construction of the [[Chennakesava Temple|Chennakeshava Temple]] at Belur and the [[Hoysaleswara temple|Hoysaleshwara Temple]] at Halebidu.<ref name="arch-tradition">Sen (1999), pp500–501</ref> Both these temples were built in commemoration of the victories of the Hoysala [[Vishnuvardhana]] against the Cholas in 1116.<ref name="chenna">Foekema (1996), p14</ref><ref name="chenna1">Kamath (2001), p124</ref> [[Veera Ballala II]], the most effective of the Hoysala rulers, defeated the aggressive Pandya when they invaded the Chola kingdom and assumed the titles "Establisher of the Chola Kingdom" (''Cholarajyapratishtacharya''), "Emperor of the south" (''Dakshina Chakravarthi'') and "Hoysala emperor" (''Hoysala Chakravarthi'').<ref name="oustand">The most outstanding of the Hoysala kings according to Barrett and William Coelho in Kamath (2001), p126</ref> The Hoysalas extended their foothold in areas known today as Tamil Nadu around 1225, making the city of Kannanur Kuppam near [[Srirangam]] a provincial capital.<ref name="provincial" /> This gave them control over South Indian politics that began a period of Hoysala hegemony in the southern Deccan.<ref name="kuppam">B.S.K. Iyengar in Kamath (2001), p126</ref><ref name="kuppam1">Keay (2000), p252</ref>
In the early 13th century, with the Hoysala power remaining unchallenged, the first of the [[Muslim]] incursions into [[South India]] began. After over two decades of waging war against a foreign power, the Hoysala ruler at the time, [[Veera Ballala III]], died in the battle of [[Madurai]] in 1343.<ref name="mad">Sen (1999), p500</ref> This resulted in the merger of the sovereign territories of the Hoysala empire with the areas administered by [[Harihara I]], founder of the [[Vijayanagara Empire]], located in the [[Tungabhadra]] region in present-day Karnataka. The new kingdom thrived for another two centuries with [[Vijayanagara]] as its capital.<ref name="origin">Two theories exist about the origin of Harihara I and his brother Bukka Raya I. One states that they were [[Kannadiga]] commanders of the Hoysala army and another that they were [[Telugu language|Telugu]] speakers and commanders of the earlier [[Kakatiya dynasty|Kakatiya Kingdom]] (Kamath 2001, pp 159–160)</ref>
==Vijayanagara Empire== {{See also|Vijayanagara Empire|Kannada literature in Vijayanagara empire|Vijayanagara Architecture}} [[Image:Vijayanagara-empire-map.svg|thumb|right|[[Vijayanagara Empire]] in 1446 CE, 1520 CE.]] <!--[[Image:Balakrishna temple DK.jpg|thumb|right|Balakrishna Temple at [[Hampi]]]]-->
The Vijayanagara Empire quickly rose to imperial status as early as the late 14th century. During the reign of [[Bukka Raya I]], the island of [[Sri Lanka|Lanka]] paid tributes and ambassadors were exchanged with the [[Ming Dynasty]] of China.<ref name="ming">Sastri (1955), p241</ref><ref name="ming2">Chopra (2003), p28, part2</ref><ref name="ming3">Indicated by records of the Ming dynasty (Kamath 2001, p162)</ref> The empire's most famous rulers were [[Deva Raya II]] and the [[Tuluva]] king [[Krishnadevaraya]]. Deva Raya II (known as ''Gajabetekara'' or hunter of elephants) ascended the throne in 1424 and was the most effective of the [[Sangama Dynasty|Sangama dynasty]] rulers.<ref name="deva">Sastri (1955), p244</ref><ref name="deva10">Chopra (2003), p32, part2</ref> He quelled rebelling feudal lords, the Zamorin of [[Kozhikode|Calicut]] and the [[Kollam|Quilon]] in the south, and invaded the island of [[Sri Lanka|Lanka]] while becoming overlord of the kings of [[Burma]] at Pegu and Tanasserim.<ref name="deva1">Chopra (2003), p32, part2; From the notes of Persian Abdur Razzak. Writings of Nuniz confirms that the kings of Burma paid tributes to Vijayanagara empire (Sastri 1955, p245)</ref><ref name="deva2">Kamath (2001), p164</ref> After a brief decline, the empire reached its peak in the early 16th century during the rule of [[Krishnadevaraya]] when the Vijayanagara armies were consistently victorious. The empire annexed areas formerly under the Sultanates in the northern Deccan and the territories in the eastern Deccan, including Kalinga, while simultaneously maintaining control over all its subordinates in the south.<ref name="deva6">Chopra (2003), pp37–39, part2; The notes of Portuguese Barbosa during the time of Krishnadevaraya confirms a very rich and well provided Vijayanagara city (Kamath 2001, p186)</ref> [[Image:Stone Chariot at the Vitthala Temple in Hampi.jpg|thumb|left|Stone Chariot [[Hampi]]]] Many important monuments at [[Hampi]] were either completed or commissioned during the reign of Krishnadevaraya. The enduring legacy of this empire is the vast open-air theatre of monuments at the regal capital, [[Vijayanagara]], which is now a UNESCO World Heritage site. [[Vijayanagara Architecture|Vijayanagara architecture]] is a vibrant blend of the preceding Chalukya, Hoysala, Pandya and Chola styles.<ref name="art">Chopra (2003), p177, part2; Art critic, [[Percy Brown (scholar)|Percy Brown]] calls Vijayanagar architecture a blossoming of Dravidian style–Kamath (2001), p182</ref> Literature in Telugu, Kannada, Tamil and Sanskrit languages found royal patronage. Telugu attained its height in popularity and reached its peak under Krishnadevaraya.<ref name="deva7">Chopra (2003), pp171–173, part2; Kamath (2001), pp181–182</ref> The Kannada [[Haridasa]] movement contributed greatly to [[Carnatic music]] and fostered a strong Hindu sentiment across South India.<ref name="father">Owing to his contributions to carnatic music, Purandaradasa is known as ''Karnataka Sangita Pitamaha''.{{cite web|title=Purandara Dasa|url=http://www.kamat.com/indica/faiths/bhakti/purandara.htm|author=Dr. Jyotsna Kamat|publisher=Kamats Potpourri|work=|accessdate=2006-12-31}}</ref><ref name="father1">{{cite web|title=Sri Purandara Dasaru|url=http://www.dvaita.org/haridasa/dasas/purandara/purandara.html|author=Madhusudana Rao CR|publisher=Dvaita Home Page|work=|accessdate=2006-12-31}}</ref><ref name="father2">{{cite web|title=History of Music|url=http://carnatica.net/origin.htm|author=S. Sowmya, K. N. Shashikiran|publisher=Srishti's Carnatica Private Limited|work=|accessdate=2006-12-31}}</ref> With the defeat of the Vijayanagara Empire in the [[Battle of Talikota]] in 1565 by the Deccan sultanates, the Karnataka region and South India in general became fragmented and subsumed under the rule of various former feudatories of the empire. A diminished Vijayanagara Empire moved its capital to Penukonda in modern Andhra Pradesh and later to [[Chandragiri]] and [[Vellore]] before disintegrating. In the south and coastal Karnataka region, the [[Kingdom of Mysore]] and the [[Keladi Nayaka]] of Shimoga held sway while the northern regions were under the control of the Bijapur Sultanate.<ref name="break">Kamath (2001), p174</ref> The Nayaka kingdom lasted into the 18th century before merging with the Kingdom of Mysore which remained a princely state until Indian independence in 1947, though they came under the British Raj (rule) in 1799 following the defeat and death of the last independent Mysore king, Tipu Sultan.
==Bahmani Sultanate== {{Main article|Bahmani Sultanate}} [[Image:Bahamani-sultanate-map.svg|thumb|right|[[Bahmani Sultanate]] territories, 1470.]]
The [[Bahmani Sultanate]], a contemporary of the Vijayanagara Empire, was founded in 1347 by Alla-ud-din-Hasan, a breakaway commander of the armies of the northern invaders led by [[Muhammad bin Tughluq|Mohammed-bin-Tughlaq]]. The capital was [[Gulbarga]] but was later moved further north to [[Bidar]] in 1430.<ref name="bin">Chopra (2003), p53, part2; Kamath (2001), p190</ref> The first of the Muslim invasions of the Deccan came in the early decades of the 14th century. At its peak, the Bahamani kingdom extended from the [[Krishna River]] in the south to [[Penganga River]] in the north, thus covering the regions of northern parts of modern Karnataka, parts of [[Maharashtra]] and [[Andhra Pradesh]]. The most famous of the Bahamani Kings was Firuz Shah (also known as Taj Ud Din Firuz), who ruled from 1397 to 1422.<ref name="firuz">Chopra (2003), pp56–57, part2; Kamath (2001), p191</ref> Militarily, the rule of Firuz Shah had uneven success against the Vijayanagara kings while he was more convincingly successful against the Kherla rulers of [[Madhya Pradesh]] and the Vema Reddies of [[Rajamundry]], areas that he annexed in 1417. His last encounter with the Vijayanagara armies in 1417 was disastrous and led to his defeat, ill health and ultimate death in 1422.<ref name="firuz"/>
Contemporary writers such as Tabataba, in his writings have heaped praise on Firuz Shah. Tabataba wrote of the king as, "[a]n impetuous, mighty monarch who patronised learned men, Sheiks and hermits", while Shirazi described him as "a just, pious and generous king and one without equal". He has earned the honorific ''Sultan-i-ghazian'' for his bravery, tolerant nature and patronage of the fine arts.<ref name="shirazi">Chopra (2003), p57, part2; Kamath (2001), p192</ref> In the opinion of one historian, Firuz Shah was one of the most notable Sultans to rule in India.<ref name="shah">Sinha in Kamath (2001), p192</ref> Another well-known figure from this kingdom was Kwaja Mahamud Gavan, the prime minister, who served under several kings and regents. He rose above the kings and princess of the dynasty by virtue of his ministerial, administrative, martial, literary and philanthropic abilities. A Persian by descent and a visitor to Bidar in 1445, he impressed the ruling Sultan Alla-ud-din II and was chosen to become a minister in his court. As a commander he was able to extend the kingdom from [[Hubli]] in the south to Goa in the west and Kondavidu and Rajamahendri in the east. He soon rose to the position of prime minister (''Vakil-Us-Sultanat'').<ref name="gavan">Chopra (2003), p63, part2; Kamath (2001), p195</ref>
The Bahamanis introduced the large-scale use of paper in administration and began the Indo-Sarasenic architectural style, designed and constructed by Persian architects and artisans, (also known as ''Deccani'' architecture) with its local influences in Karnataka.<ref name="gavan1">Chopra (2003), pp181–182, part2; Kamath (2001), p198</ref> The Sultanate monuments of Bidar and Gulbarga are testimony to their interest in architecture. The Bande Nawaz tombs and a Jama Masjid in Gulbarga which exhibits a Spanish influence are well known. In Bidar, their buildings have Persian, Turkish, Arabic and Roman influences (the Solah Khamba mosque being an example).<ref name="Turk">Kamath (2001), p198</ref> Rangin Mahal, Gangan Mahal, Tarkash Mahal, Chini Mahal, Nagina Mahal and the Taqk Mahal are some of the palaces built by them that have retained their beauty. The Ahmad Shah Wali tombs are noted for their decor, and the school of learning (''madrasa'') built by Gavan in Bidar (1472), with its lecture halls, library, mosque and residential houses are also famous.<ref name="tomb">Chopra (2003), p182, part2; Kamath (2001), p199</ref> In the later part of the 15th century, with a growing rift between the local Deccani Muslims and the ''Pardeshi'' Muslims (foreign) who occupied influential positions in the kingdom, the execution of Gavan under dubious circumstances in 1481, and constant wars with the Vijayanagara kings weakened the Bahamani Kingdom eventually bringing about its end in 1527.<ref name="end">Chopra (2003), p62, pp64–65, part2; Kamath (2001), p194</ref>
==Bijapur Sultanate== {{Main article|Bijapur Sultanate}} [[Image:Bijapur-sultanate-map.svg|thumb|right|[[Bijapur Sultanate]] territories under Ibrahim II, 1620 CE.]]
The [[Bijapur Sultanate]] (or Adilshahi Kingdom) emerged towards the end of the 15th century with the weakening of the Bahmani Sultanate . The main sources of information about this kingdom comes from contemporaneous inscriptions and writings in Persian and Kannada, travelogues of European visitors to the Deccan and inscriptions of neighbouring kingdoms.<ref name="bija">Kamath (2001), p200</ref> In 1489, Yusuf Adilkhan, a [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] general in the Bahmani army, broke away to found the kingdom from modern Bijapur . Throughout his rule, the Sultanate was at war with the Vijayanagara Empire over the strategic [[Raichur]] doab, with the Portuguese over [[Goa]], with the Barid Shahis of Bidar and later with the erstwhile feudatories of the Vijayanagara Empire who had gained independence after 1565. The [[Italy|Italian]] writer Varathema wrote about the founder Adilkhan and Bijapur, "A powerful and prosperous king", "the city was encircled by many fortifications and contained beautiful and majestic buildings".<ref name="bija"/>
Inter-Sultanate marriages normalised relations and Ali I (1557–1580) joined a confederacy of Sultanates who eventually inflicted a crushing defeat on the Vijayanagara Empire in 1565.<ref name="conf">Kamath (2001), p201</ref> The most notable ruler of the dynasty was Ibrahim II (1580–1626) who ascended the throne as a nine-year-old with Chandbibi, the king's aunt acting as the regent. Later when Ibrahim II was defeated by the first of the Moghul incursions into the Deccan, he gave his daughter in marriage to Daniyal, a son of Emperor [[Akbar]], but managed to collect tributes from the former feudatories of the Vijayanagara Empire.<ref name="erst">Kamath (2001), p202</ref> According to a historian, the rule of Ibrahim II was the high point of the Bijapur Sultanate.<ref name="high">Sinha in Kamath (2001), p2002</ref> A tolerant king inclined to the fine arts, the earliest book on music in Urdu language called ''Kitab-e-Nauras'' is ascribed to him. The opening song in the book is an invocation of the Hindu Goddess [[Saraswati]].<ref name="erst"/> During the rule of his son Muhammad, Shahji Bhosle from [[Ahmadnagar]] joined the Bijapur army and along with commander Ranadullah Khan conducted many successful campaigns in the southern Deccan collecting tribute from local rulers there. The final end of the diminished Vijayanagara Empire ruling from [[Vellore]] came during these campaigns.<ref name="camp">Kamath (2001), p203</ref> [[Image:GolGumbaz2.jpg|thumb|left|[[Gol Gumbaz]] at [[Bijapur, Karnataka|Bijapur]], has the second largest pre-modern dome in the world after the Byzantine [[Hagia Sophia]].]] However, the rise of [[Maratha empire|Maratha]] [[Shivaji]] and constant invasions by the [[Mughal (tribe)|Mughals]] from the north took its toll on the kingdom, eventually bringing it to an end in the later part of the 17th century. The contributions of the Bijapur Sultanate in the Indo-Saracenic idiom to the architectural landscape of Karnataka is noteworthy. Their most famous monuments are the mausoleums called Ibrahim Rauza and the [[Gol Gumbaz]] apart from many other palaces and mosques.<ref name="gol">Kamath (2001), p207</ref> The elegance, finish and beauty of Mehtar Mahal is claimed by a historian to be equal to anything in [[Cairo]].<ref name="cairo">Fergusson in Kamath (2001), p207</ref> Their Kali Masjid at [[Lakshmeshwar]] is a synthesis of Hindu and Muslim styles. The Ibrahim Rauza built by Ibrahim II is a combination of a mausoleum and a mosque and is called the "[[Taj Mahal]] of the Deccan".<ref name="taj">Fergusson in Kamath (2001), p208</ref> The [[Gol Gumbaz]] built by Muhammad is the largest dome in India and the second largest pre-modern dome in the world after the Byzantine [[Hagia Sophia]] with an impressive "whispering gallery". Some historians consider this one of the architectural marvels of the world.<ref name="gumbuz">Kamath (2001), p209</ref> Persian language was given state patronage while the use of the local languages, Kannada and Marathi was popularised in local affairs.<ref name="localaffairs">Kamath (2001), p206</ref>
==Modern era== {{See also|Kingdom of Mysore}} [[Image:Indian Mysore Kingdom 1784 map.svg|thumb|right|200px|[[Kingdom of Mysore]] under [[Tipu Sultan]].]] [[Image:Mysore Palace at dusk.jpg|thumb|left|[[Mysore Palace]] at dusk (Indo-Saracenic style).]] The fall of the Vijayanagara Empire in 1565 at the [[Battle of Talikota]] started a slow disintegration of the Kannada speaking region into many short-lived ''palegar'' chiefdoms, and the better known [[Kingdom of Mysore]] and the kingdom of [[Keladi Nayaka]]s, which were to later become important centres of Kannada literary production.<ref name="tali">Nagaraj in Pollock (2003), p370; Kamath (2001), p171, p174</ref> These kingdoms and the Nayakas ("chiefs") of Tamil country continued to owe nominal support to a diminished Vijayanagara Empire ruling from [[Penukonda]] (1570) and later from [[Chandragiri]] (1586) in modern [[Andhra Pradesh]], followed by a brief period of independence.<ref name="nominal">Subrahmanyam (2001), pp67–68; Kamath (2001), pp173–174</ref> By the mid-17th century, large areas in north Karnataka came under the control of the [[Bijapur Sultanate]] who waged several wars in a bid to establish a hegemony over the southern Deccan.<ref name="vel">Chopra (2003), p96, part2; Kamath (2006), pp173–174</ref> The defeat of the Bijapur Sultanate at the hands of the [[Mughals]] in late 17th century added a new dimension to the prevailing confusion.<ref name="dim">Chopra (2003), pp101; Kamath (2006), p204</ref> The constant wars of the local kingdoms with the two new rivals, the Mughals and the [[Marathas]], and among themselves, caused further instability in the region.<ref name="lek">Kamath (2001), p226</ref> Major areas of Karnataka came under the rule of the Mughals and the Marathas. Under [[Hyder Ali]] and his son [[Tipu Sultan]], the Mysore Kingdom reached its zenith of power but had to face the growing English might who by now had a firm foothold in the subcontinent.<ref name="tip">Chopra (2003), p71, part3; Kamath (2001), p231–234</ref> After the death of Tipu Sultan in 1799 in the fourth Anglo-Mysore war, the Mysore Kingdom came under the British umbrella.<ref name="fell">Chopra (2003), pp80–81, part3</ref> More than a century later, with the dawn of India as an independent nation in 1947, the [[Unification of Karnataka|unification of Kannada speaking regions]] as modern Karnataka state brought four centuries of political uncertainty (and centuries of foreign rule) to an end.
