revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/92.29.240.219|92.29.240.219]] ([[User talk:92.29.240.219|talk]]): The statue is similar however not a copy. There are fundamental differences. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{original research|date=February 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2011}} Hundreds of [[replica]]s of the [[Statue of Liberty]] (''Liberty Enlightening the World'') have been created worldwide.
==France== ===Paris=== ====Musée d'Orsay==== [[File:Statue de la liberte.jpg|thumb|left|The Exposition Universelle model in its previous location in the [[Jardin du Luxembourg]], Paris]] On the occasion of the [[Exposition Universelle (1900)|Exposition Universelle of 1900]], [[Frédéric Bartholdi]] crafted a smaller version of ''Liberty Enlightening the World'', which he subsequently gave to the Musée du Luxembourg. In 1905, the statue was placed outside the museum in the [[Jardin du Luxembourg]], where it stood for over a century, until 2014. It currently stands within the entrance hall to the [[Musée d'Orsay]], and a newly constructed bronze replica stands in its place in the Jardin du Luxembourg.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/collections/overview/actualites/lady-liberty-in-orsay.html#c67912 |title=The Musée d'Orsay's Liberty |website=[[Musée d'Orsay]] |accessdate=August 1, 2017}}</ref>
====Île aux Cygnes==== [[File:Statue of Liberty Paris 001.jpg|thumb|Statue of Liberty on the [[Île aux Cygnes]], River Seine in Paris. Given to the city in 1889, it faces southwest, downriver along the Seine.]] This statue was given in 1889 to France by U.S. citizens<ref name=nytimes>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D00E4DE143AEF33A25756C0A9619C94689FD7CF |title=France's Liberty Statue; A Copy of that on Bedlow's Island. Ceremonies at the Inauguration in Paris of the Replica of Bartholdi's Great Work |date=July 5, 1889 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=August 1, 2017}}</ref> living in Paris to celebrate the [[French Revolution]] three years after the main statue in New York was inaugurated. In 1937, the statue was turned from looking east to looking west straight to the direction of the New York's statue.
The statue is near the [[Pont de Grenelle|Grenelle Bridge]] on the [[Île aux Cygnes]], a man-made island in the [[Seine]] ({{Coord|48|51|0|N|2|16|47|E|}}). It is {{convert|11.50|m|ftin|abbr=off}} high and weighs 14 tons.<ref name=japantimes>{{cite news |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/1998/04/28/national/statue-illumination-kicks-off-year-of-france-event/ |title=Statue illumination kicks off ‘Year of France’ event |date=April 28, 1998 |newspaper=[[Japan Times]] |accessdate=October 4, 2015}}</ref> Inaugurated on July 4, 1889, it looks southwest, downriver along the Seine. Its tablet bears two dates: "IV JUILLET 1776" (July 4, 1776: the [[United States Declaration of Independence]]) like the New York statue, and "XIV JUILLET 1789" (July 14, 1789: the [[storming of the Bastille]]) associated with an equal sign. This statue is shown in the film ''[[National Treasure: Book of Secrets]]'' as a historic location.
====Musée des Arts et Métiers==== The {{convert|2.86|m|ft|adj=on}} tall original plaster [[maquette]] finished in 1878 by Auguste Bartholdi that was used to make the statue in New York is in the [[Musée des Arts et Métiers]] in Paris.<ref>{{cite book |first1=Robert |last1=Belot |first2=Daniel |last2=Bermond |title=Bartholdi |location=Paris |publisher=Éditions Perrin |year=2004 |isbn=978-2-26201-991-4}}</ref><ref>E. L. Kallop, Jr., ''Images of Liberty. Models and reductions of the Statue of Liberty 1867–1917'', Special Centennial Exhibition 25 Janvier–15 Février 1986</ref> This original plaster was bequeathed by the artist's widow in 1907,<ref>Legal instrument prepared by M. Demanche, notary, on March 1, 1907 (Inv13768ter in the Museum archives).</ref> together with part of the artist's estate.
On the square outside the Musée des Arts et Métiers{{'}}s entrance is a bronze copy made from the plaster maquette, number 1 from an original edition of 12, made by the museum and cast by Susse Fondeur Paris.
====''Flame of Liberty''==== A life-size copy of the torch, ''[[Flame of Liberty]]'', can be seen above the entrance to the [[Pont de l'Alma]] tunnel near the [[Champs-Élysées]] in Paris. It was given to the city as a return gift in honor of the centennial celebration of the statue's dedication. Since it is above the Pont de l'Alma car tunnel in which [[Princess Diana]] died, the torch became an unofficial memorial to the princess.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,624681,00.html |title=Paris Honors Diana with Two Memorials |date=August 28, 2002 |first=Stephen M. |last=Silverman |magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]}}</ref>
===Barentin=== There is a replica in the northwest of France, in the small town of Barentin near [[Rouen]]. It was made for a French movie, ''Le Cerveau'' ("The Brain"), directed by Gérard Oury and featuring actors [[Jean-Paul Belmondo]] and [[Bourvil]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statueofliberty.info/pages/statue/mondeba.htm |title=Les Statues dans le monde |accessdate=May 28, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060210152719/http://www.statueofliberty.info/pages/statue/mondeba.htm |archivedate=February 10, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy}}: image and description of the Barentin replica from the personal website of a Statue of Liberty enthusiast.</ref>
===Bordeaux=== Another replica is a {{convert|2.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} statue in the city of [[Bordeaux]]. The first Bordeaux statue was seized and melted down by the Nazis in World War II. The statue was replaced in 2000 and a plaque was added to commemorate the victims of the [[September 11, 2001 attacks|September 11 terrorist attacks]]. On the night of March 25, 2003, unknown vandals poured red paint and gasoline on the replica and set it on fire. The vandals also cracked the pedestal of the plaque. The mayor of Bordeaux, former prime minister [[Alain Juppé]], condemned the attack.
===Colmar=== [[File:ColmarStatueLibertérRéplique.jpg|thumb|Replica of the Statue of Liberty in [[Colmar]]]] A {{convert|12|m|ftin|abbr=on}} replica of the Statue of Liberty in [[Colmar]], the city of [[Frédéric Bartholdi|Bartholdi's]] birth, was dedicated on July 4, 2004, to commemorate the 100th anniversary of his death. It stands at the north entrance of the city.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.endex.com/gf/buildings/liberty/worldstatues/liberties/Colmar/LibertyColmar.htm |title=Statue of Freedom, Colmar, Alsace, France, Birthplace of Auguste Bartholdi |first=Gary |last=Feuerstein |website=endex.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615191834/http://www.endex.com/gf/buildings/liberty/worldstatues/liberties/Colmar/LibertyColmar.htm |archivedate=June 15, 2010}}</ref> The Bartholdi Museum in Colmar contains numerous models of various sizes made by Bartholdi during the process of designing the statue.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cr.nps.gov/history/online_books/hh/11/hh11e.htm |title=Construction of the Statue |date=September 25, 2000 |website=National Park Service Historical Handbook |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604150524/http://www.cr.nps.gov/history/online_books/hh/11/hh11e.htm |archivedate=June 4, 2011}}</ref>
===Saint-Cyr-sur-Mer=== Frédéric Bartholdi donated a copy of the Statue of Liberty to the town square of [[Saint-Cyr-sur-Mer]].
===Other French cities=== Other ''Liberty Enlightening the World'' statues are displayed in [[Poitiers]] and [[Lunel]]. The [[Musée des beaux-arts de Lyon]] owns a terracotta version.
Near [[Chaumont, Haute Marne]], is a miniature replica in the flag plaza of the former [[Chaumont Air Base]]. This was the home of the US 48th Tactical Fighter Wing, now based at Lakenheath, England, with its own statue at the flag plaza. The 48th TFW is the only USAF wing with a name: "The Statue of Liberty Wing".
Another example is of a ''Liberty Enlightening the World'' replica in [[Châteauneuf-la-Forêt]], near the city of [[Limoges]] in the area of [[Haute-Vienne]], [[Limousin (region)|Limousin]]. There is another "original" Bartholdi replica at [[Roybon]] (near Grenoble)
There is a small replica on [[Boulevard des Anglais]] in [[Nice]].
==Other European countries== ===Austria=== In [[Minimundus]], a [[miniature park]] located at the [[Wörthersee]] in [[Carinthia (state)|Carinthia]], Austria, is another replica of the Statue of Liberty.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.minimundus.at/img/bildarchiv/ba_10_gross.jpg |title=Minimundus replica |website=minimundus.at |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070317230345/http://www.minimundus.at/img/bildarchiv/ba_10_gross.jpg |archivedate=March 17, 2007}}</ref>
In Graz, standing between the [[Graz Opera|Opera House]] and the NextLiberty Theater, stands a steel structure built out of steel beams, that depict the original size of the statue of liberty, before the plates of the final form were being put into place. Instead of torch of flame, this depiction is holding a sword in extended left arm and a sphere in the right arm representing the world.
===Denmark=== A small replica in lego is situated in [[Legoland Billund Resort|Legoland]] in [[Billund, Denmark|Billund]].
===Germany=== A {{convert|35|m|ft|abbr=on}} copy is in the German ''[[Heide Park|Heidepark Soltau]]'' theme park, located on a lake with cruising Mississippi steamboats. It weighs 28 metric tons (31 short tons), is made of plastic foam on a steel frame with polyester cladding, and was designed by the Dutch artist Gerla Spee.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heidepark.de/swf/assets/parkplan.jpg |title=Freizeitpark und Familienpark in Soltau |website=Heide Park Resort |accessdate=August 1, 2017}}</ref>
===Ireland=== A green painted replica of the Statue of Liberty can be found near Mulnamina More, [[County Donegal]], Ireland.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.flickriver.com/photos/70302078@N00/3140281654 |title=Flickriver Photo |website=Flickriver.com |date=August 15, 2004 |accessdate=March 19, 2012}}</ref>
===Kosovo=== A replica stands atop the Hotel Victory in [[Pristina]], Kosovo.<ref>{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Morgan |title=Investors should take a closer look at Kosovo |newspaper=[[Denver Business Journal]] |date=July 25, 2003|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2003/07/28/editorial4.html |quote=It was quite a change to arrive in Pristina, where the main street is named after Bill Clinton and my hotel, the Hotel Victory, has a replica of the Statue of Liberty built on its rooftop.}}</ref>
=== Netherlands === [[File:Drents Vrijheidsbeeld.jpg|thumb|Replica of the Statue of Liberty in [[Assen]], the Netherlands]] A 33 ft (10 m) replica has its temporary location in the Dutch city of [[Assen]]. The statue bears characteristic features that represent the culture and landscape of the region, like a can of beans instead of the original torch. The replica, by sculptor Natasja Bennink, is on display for the duration of an exhibition on American Realism in the [[Drents Museum]] until 27 May 2018.
===Norway=== A smaller replica is in the Norwegian village of [[Visnes, Rogaland|Visnes]], where the copper used in the original statue was mined.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.olavsrosa.no/en/objektinfo.aspx?id=27787 |title=Vigsnes Mining Field |website=Olavsrosa.no |date=July 28, 2007 |accessdate=March 19, 2012}}</ref> A replica is also on the facade of a pub in [[Bleik]], county of [[Nordland]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nesthus.net/index.php?p=foto&l=en&bid=Array&bi=262 |title=Nesthus |website=nesthus.net |accessdate=August 1, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201181543/http://nesthus.net/index.php?p=foto&l=en&bid=Array&bi=262 |archivedate=February 1, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bt.no/reise/Pa-spontanferie-mellom-himmel-og-hav-1780575.html#.UuEZm4Y1hFk |title=På spontanferie mellom himmel og hav |first=Christina |last=Pletten |date=July 12, 2010 |newspaper=[[Bergens Tidende]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=August 1, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113130258/http://www.bt.no/reise/Pa-spontanferie-mellom-himmel-og-hav-1780575.html#.UuEZm4Y1hFk |archivedate=January 13, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Spain=== [[File:Estatua de la libertad en Cadaqués - de cerca - panoramio.jpg|thumb|left|Replica of the Statue of Liberty in [[Cadaqués]], Spain]] * In 1897 a {{convert|123|cm|ftin|abbr=on}} replica in iron and bronze was erected in [[Cenicero]], Spain, to honor local fighters during the [[First Carlist War]]. In 1936 it was removed during [[Spain under Franco|the dictatorship of Francisco Franco]]. It was restored in 1976. * The [[:ca:Biblioteca Pública Arús|Rossend Arús public library]] in [[Barcelona]] has in its entrance a {{convert|2|m|ftin|abbr=on}} replica from 1894. She welcomes visitors to the library, which is devoted to the [[labour movement]], [[anarchism]], and [[freemasonry]]. * [[Cadaqués]], a small village that was residence of [[Salvador Dalí]], has an unusual version, with both hands up. It is on top of a small tourism information office.
===Ukraine=== There is a unique "sitting" Statue of Liberty in the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] city of [[Lviv]]. It is a sculpture on a dome of the house (15, Freedom Avenue) built by architect Yuriy Zakharevych and decorated by sculptor [[Leandro Marconi]] in 1874–91.
===United Kingdom=== [[File:Statue of Liberty Leicester UK.jpg|thumb|Replica of the Statue of Liberty in [[Leicester, England]]]] A {{convert|17|ft|m|abbr=on}}, 9,200 kg (9.2 tons) replica stood atop the Liberty Shoe factory in [[Leicester]], England, until 2002 when the building was demolished. The statue was put into storage while the building was replaced. The statue, which dates back to the 1920s, was initially going to be put back on the replacement building, but was too heavy, so in December 2008 following restoration, it was placed on a pedestal near Liberty Park Halls of Residence on a traffic island, "Liberty Circus", close to where it originally stood.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/leicestershire/7478419.stm |title=Landmark could return to skyline |date=June 27, 2008 |website=BBC News |accessdate=August 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leicester.gov.uk/newssite/index01.asp?pgid=8903 |title=Work begins on replacing statue |date=November 20, 2008 |website=Leicester City Council |accessdate=August 1, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227051726/http://www.leicester.gov.uk/newssite/index01.asp?pgid=8903 |archivedate=December 27, 2008}}</ref>
A {{convert|10|ft|m|adj=mid|-high}} replica is in the stairwell of a bowling alley building in Warrington, England. It used to be above the entrance of a restaurant nearby.
There is also a small replica located at [[RAF Lakenheath]], England, at the base flag plaza, made from leftover copper from the original.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lakenheath.af.mil/shared/media/document/AFD-070730-006.pdf |title=Press release |page=4 |website=lakenheath.af.mil}}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
==North America==
===Canada=== In [[Coquitlam]], [[British Columbia]] a small replica stands on Delestre Avenue just east of North Road.<ref>{{cite web |title=Statue of Liberty replica in Coquitlam, BC on Google Street View |url=https://www.google.ca/maps/@49.2423537,-122.8919028,3a,75y,33.39h,88.12t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sQXBS89jbWzou5rL1mmQSpw!2e0!7i13312!8i6656!6m1!1e1?hl=en |accessdate=December 20, 2015}}</ref>
===Mexico=== * In [[Campeche]], Mexico, there is a small replica in the small town of [[Palizada]].
* In [[Durango]], Mexico, a small replica is in Parque Guadiana. This park also has other small reproductions such as the [[Eiffel Tower]] and [[Taj Mahal]].

It was presented to the city by some of Bartholdi's descendants residing in Duluth.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ci.duluth.mn.us/city/artscommission/otherpublicart.htm |title=Other Public Art |website=City of Duluth |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624012727/http://www.ci.duluth.mn.us/city/artscommission/otherpublicart.htm |archivedate=June 24, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.geocaching.com/seek/log.aspx?IID=109677de-7cf1-444a-a51b-d53f970cb5d2&LID=9353315 |title=Photograph of Duluth replica |website=geocaching.com}}</ref> * The [[Boy Scouts of America]] celebrated their fortieth anniversary in 1950 with the theme of "[[Strengthen the Arm of Liberty]]".<ref>{{cite journal |title=Little Sisters of Liberty |journal=Scouting |date=October 2007 |last=Attoun |first=Marti |url=http://www.scoutingmagazine.org/issues/0710/d-wwas.html |accessdate=October 9, 2007}}</ref> Between 1949 and 1952, approximately two hundred {{convert|100|in|m|adj=on}} replicas of the statue, made of stamped copper, were purchased by Boy Scout troops and donated in 39 states in the U.S. and several of its possessions and territories. The project was the brainchild of Kansas City businessman J.P. Whitaker, who was then Scout Commissioner of the [[Kansas City Area Council]]. The copper statues were manufactured by Friedley-Voshardt Co. (Chicago, Illinois) and purchased through the Kansas City Boy Scout office by those wanting one. The statues are approximately {{convert|8+1/2|ft|m}} tall without the base, are constructed of sheet copper, weigh {{convert|290|lb|kg}}, and originally cost $350 plus freight. The mass-produced statues are not great art nor meticulously accurate (a conservator notes that "her face isn't as mature as the real Liberty. It's rounder and more like a little girl's"), but they are cherished, particularly since [[September 11, 2001 attacks|9/11]]. Many have been lost or destroyed, but preservationists have been able to account for about a hundred of them, and BSA Troop 101 of Cheyenne, Wyoming, has collected photographs of over 100 of them.<ref>{{cite web |last=Attoun |first=Marti |title=Restoring the Little Sisters of Lady Liberty |url=http://www.americanprofile.com/article/3455.html |website=American Profile |date=September 29, 2007 |accessdate=September 30, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316155830/http://www.americanprofile.com/article/3455.html |archivedate=March 16, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cheyennetroop101.org/liberty/ |title=Photos and locations of more than ninety of the replicas |website=BSA Troop 101 |location=Cheyenne, Wyoming |accessdate=August 1, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910092649/http://www.cheyennetroop101.org/liberty/ |archivedate=September 10, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> They are commonly installed at city halls, libraries, and schools. One of these statues was sent to the Philippines. After some years at the mouth of the Pasig River, Manila, it was kept in a store room at the Scout Reservation, Makiling, Laguna, for about two decades. It is now stored at the national office of the [[Boy Scouts of the Philippines]], Manila. *A nine-foot-tall replica of the Statue, built in 1950, stands in [[Warner Park]] in [[Madison, Wisconsin]].<ref name="StatueSOS">{{cite web | author= | year=1993 | title=Statue of Liberty Replica, (sculpture). | work=Save Outdoor Sculpture! | publisher=Inventories of American Painting and Sculpture | url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!328309~!0#focus | accessdate= 19 May 2011 }}</ref> * A replica of the original statue was unveiled on October 12, 2011, at 667 Madison Avenue in [[Manhattan]]. Parkway.jpg|thumb|200px|''Liberty Enlightening the World'' replica in [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]], Alabama]] * A {{convert|36|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} bronze replica, accurately based on [[Frédéric Bartholdi|Bartholdi's]] ''Liberty Enlightening the World'', stands in [[Vestavia Hills, Alabama|Vestavia Hills]], a suburb of [[Birmingham, Alabama]]. It was cast in 1956 at the ''Société Antoine Durenne'' foundry in Somerville, Haut Marne, France, for placement in 1958 atop the [[Liberty National Life Insurance Company]] building in downtown Birmingham.<ref name="BrooklynMuseum"/> It was relocated and placed on a {{convert|60|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} granite pedestal adjacent to [[Interstate 459]] in 1989.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bhamonline.com/liberty/ |title=Birmingham's Statue of Liberty |website=Birmingham Online.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060829081729/http://www.bhamonline.com/liberty/ |archivedate=August 29, 2006 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="GAStudio">{{cite web |title=Liberty Statue |website=GA Architecture Studio |url=http://www.gastudio.com/oddlots/10_missliberty/index.html |accessdate=February 17, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106191555/http://www.gastudio.com/oddlots/10_missliberty/index.html |archivedate=January 6, 2009 |df=mdy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |website=Roadside America |url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/tips/getAttraction.php3?tip_AttractionNo==13 |title=Birmingham, Alabama – Statue of Liberty Replica}}</ref> * Two {{convert|30|ft|m|adj=on}} copper replicas by sculptor [[Leo Lentelli]] stand atop the Liberty National Bank Building<ref name="BrooklynMuseum"/> in [[Buffalo, New York]], nearly {{convert|108|m|ft|abbr=on}} above street level.<ref>{{cite web |title=Liberty Building |url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=126216 |website=Emporis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Buffalo – Liberty Building |url=http://www.planetware.com/buffalo/liberty-building-us-ny-lib.htm |website=PlanetWare}}</ref> * A {{convert|25|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} replica sits on the ruins of the late [[Marysville Bridge]] (erected on a platform (pier)) in the Dauphin Narrows of [[Susquehanna River]] north of [[Harrisburg]]. The replica was built by a local activist [[Gene Stilp]] on July 2, 1986; it was made of Venetian blinds and stood {{convert|18|ft|m}} tall. Six years later, after it was destroyed in a windstorm, it was rebuilt by Stilp and other local citizens, of wood, metal, glass and fiberglass, to a height of {{convert|25|ft|m}}.<ref>{{cite news |last=Scolforo |first=Mark |year=2004 |url=http://www.phillyburbs.com/pb-dyn/news/103-02142004-246490.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20080108084232/http://www.phillyburbs.com/pb-dyn/news/103-02142004-246490.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-01-08 |title=Master of props lends visual effects to memorable publicity campaigns |agency=Associated Press }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |website=U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service |url=http://www.fish.state.pa.us/watertrails/susqmid/trailguide.htm |title=Susquehanna River Trail: Dauphin Narrows/Statue of Liberty}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.facstaff.bucknell.edu/kochel/classes/susqriver/august31.htm |first=R. Craig |last=Kochel |title=Photograph of the Stilp statue |website=Facstaff.bucknell.edu |date= |accessdate=March 19, 2012}}</ref> * A [[Lego]] replica of the Statue of Liberty consisting of 2882 bricks and standing {{convert|0.9|m|ft|abbr=on}} is a popular sculpture among Lego enthusiasts. The statue went out of production, but due to popular demand was returned to sale.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/10907 |title=Statue of Liberty Sculpture (#3450-1) |website=RoadSide America |date= |accessdate=July 31, 2012}}</ref> * A 1/12 replica of the Statue of Liberty made essentially out of junk stands at the intersection of [[US 280]] and [[US 341]] in [[McRae, Georgia]]. The head is made out of a stump from a nearby swamp, the arm holding the torch is made from [[styrofoam]] and the hand holding the book is actually an electric lineman's glove. The town's [[Lion's Club]] erected the replica in 1986 during the statue's centennial.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/10907 |title=Home-Built Statue of Liberty Replica |website=RoadSide America |date= |accessdate=May 31, 2017}}</ref> * An {{convert|11|ft|m|adj=on}} miniature Statue of Liberty (holding a Bible instead of a tablet) currently stands atop a {{convert|15|ft|m|adj=on}} pedestal outside the Liberty Recycling plant in [[San Marcos, California]]. The company was named after the statue, which has been moved throughout [[San Diego North County|northern San Diego County]] for over 80 years, originating at the Liberty Hotel in [[Encinitas, California|Leucadia]], in the 1920s.<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=[[North County Times]] |url=http://www.nctimes.com/news/local/article_4dd6b10d-d720-546e-85f9-69ac5553c1b0.html |title=Lady Liberty lowered in San Marcos |access-date=October 17, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100523160736/http://www.nctimes.com/news/local/article_4dd6b10d-d720-546e-85f9-69ac5553c1b0.html |archive-date=May 23, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * A {{convert|25|ft|m|adj=on}} replica of the statue, lofting a Christian cross, holding the Ten Commandments, and named the ''Statue of Liberation through Christ'', was erected by a predominantly African American church in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], on July 4, 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thestatueofliberationthroughchrist.org/ |title=Home |website=thestatueofliberationthroughchrist.org}}</ref> * A small replica stands on the grounds of the [[Cherokee]] Capitol Building in [[Tahlequah, Oklahoma]], a gift from the local [[Scouting in Oklahoma|Boy Scouts]] in 1950 (presumably as part of the above-mentioned national Boy Scout celebration).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lasr.net/leisure/oklahoma/cherokee/tahlequah/att3f.html |title=Statue of Liberty Replica |website=Leisure and Sport Review |year=2006 |accessdate=October 7, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060904193624/http://www.lasr.net/leisure/oklahoma/cherokee/tahlequah/att3f.html |archive-date=September 4, 2006 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * [[Fargo, North Dakota]], also has a replica of the Statue of Liberty on the corner of Main Avenue and 2nd Street at the entrance of the Main Avenue bridge.<ref>{{cite web |website=Digital Horizons |title=Statue of Liberty replica, Fargo, N.D. |url=http://digitalhorizonsonline.org/cdm/ref/collection/uw/id/5888 |accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref> * There is a replica on the shoreline of [[Lake Chaubunagungamaug]] in [[Webster, Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Belluck |first=Pam |title=What's the Name of That Lake? It's Hard to Say |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 20, 2004 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/20/national/20lake.html}}</ref> * A 1/6-scale replica (~50 feet including pedestal) stands in a parking lot of a strip mall in [[Milwaukie, Oregon]], off McLoughlin Blvd at 4255 SE Roethe Rd.<ref>{{cite web |website=Roadside America |url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/tip/15118 |title=Milwaukee, OR Statue of Liberty Replica}}</ref> * A {{convert|6|ft|sing=on}} replica stands at [[Statue of Liberty (Seattle)|Statue of Liberty Plaza]] in [[West Seattle]], Washington, at [[Alki Beach Park]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kuow.org/post/seattles-tiny-statue-liberty-0 |title=Seattle's Tiny Statue of Liberty |first=Joshua |last=McNichols |website=kuow.org |accessdate=August 1, 2017}}</ref> * A replica of the Statue of Liberty stands on [[Mackinac Island]], [[Michigan]].<ref>https://bree1972.wordpress.com/2013/09/12/lady-liberty-returns-to-mackinac-island/</ref>
==South America== ===Argentina=== In [[Buenos Aires]] there is a small iron replica in Barrancas de Belgrano Square, cast by Bartholdi from the same mould as those cast in Paris; although it is much smaller. It was inaugurated on October 3, 1886, 25 days before the one in New York. Another replica was bought by the government and placed in a school, Colegio Nacional Sarmiento, about the same date.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://turismo.perfil.com/18897-un-paseo-por-la-estatua-de-la-libertad-y-sus-hermanas-gemelas/ |title=Un paseo por la Estatua de la Libertad (y sus hermanas gemelas) |date=May 31, 2013 |newspaper=[[Perfil]] |accessdate=August 1, 2017}}</ref>. There is another replica in Plaza Libertad (Liberty Square) in the city of [[Villa Aberastain]], [[San Juan Province, Argentina|San Juan]]. This one arrived at the city in 1909 due to a confusion since it had to be shipped to San Juan, Puerto Rico instead. There are also two cheaper non-metallic replicas; one is 6 m tall, located in the "New York" Casino in [[San Luis, Argentina|San Luis]] and the other crowns a commercial gallery, "Galería de Fabricantes", in [[Munro]], a city in the northeast suburbs of Buenos Aires.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.taringa.net/posts/info/17176133/La-estatua-de-la-libertad-argentina.html |title=La Estatua de la Libertad, Argentina |website=taringa.net |accessdate=August 1, 2017}}</ref>
===Brazil=== [[File:2010-10-30 replica Statue of Liberty Maceio Alagoas Brazil.JPG|thumb|A replica of the [[Statue of Liberty]] in [[Maceió]], Alagoas, Brazil]] [[File:Barra.100.jpg|thumb|New York City Center in [[Rio de Janeiro]], Brazil]] In [[Bangu, Rio de Janeiro]] exists a [[nickel]] replica made by [[Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi|Bartholdi]] in 1899. Bartholdi was commissioned by [[José Paranhos, Baron of Rio Branco]] to make a replica in order to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the [[Brazil|Republic of Brazil]]. Until 1940, the statue was Paranhos family property. In 1940 the statue was passed to [[Guanabara State]]. In January 20, 1964 [[Carlos Lacerda]], governor of [[Guanabara State]], placed the statue in Miami Square, [[Bangu, Rio de Janeiro|Bangu]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogdaalessandravieira.blogspot.com/2011/11/historia-de-que-estatua-da-liberdade.html |first=Alessandra |last=Vieira |title=Historia de que estatua da liberdade |date=November 2011 |website=Blogspot.com |accessdate=August 1, 2017}}</ref> {{Coord|-22.856681 |-43.492577}}
A small-scale cast metal replica can be found in [[Maceió]], the capital of [[Alagoas]] State, in northeast Brazil. The replica is in front of a building constructed in 1869 as the seat of the ''Conselho Provincial'' (Provincial Council), and which today is the Museu da Imagem e do Som de Alagoas (Museum of Image and Sound of Alagoas). This replica is possibly a casting produced by the [[:pt:Fundição Val d'Osne|Fundição Val d'Osne]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.revistadehistoria.com.br/v2/home/?go=detalhe&id=2341 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120914094154/http://www.revistadehistoria.com.br/v2/home/?go=detalhe&id=2341 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 14, 2012 |title=Quando o ferro virou arte |website=Revista de História |date=December 4, 2009 |accessdate=July 31, 2012}}</ref> in France, as in the Praça Lavenere Machado (formerly Praça Dois Leões) on the opposite side of the museum, there are four somewhat larger-than-life size cast metal statues of wild animals, at least one of which is embossed with the name of the foundry. These castings and the replica all appear to be made of similar material and to be of similar age. It is also probable that they are near contemporaries of the actual Statue of Liberty. {{Coord|-9.6728563|-35.7223114}}
A large modern replica stands in front of the New York City Center, a shopping center constructed in 1999 in [[Barra da Tijuca]] in the [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|State of Rio de Janeiro]]. {{Coord|-22.9992837|-43.360481}}
The Havan department store chain has replicas in many of their stores. The largest one of these, 57 meters tall,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://folha1.blogspot.com.br/2012/10/conheca-as-5-maiores-estatuas-do-brasil.html |title=Conheça as 5 Maiores Estátuas do Brasil |author=Guilherme |date=October 2012 |website=blogspot.com.br |accessdate=August 1, 2017}}</ref> is allegedly in the [[Barra Velha]] branc, in the state of [[Santa Catarina (state)|Santa Catarina]].{{Coord|-26.635870|-48.698708}} There is another large replica the parking area of a Havan Department Store on the outskirts of [[Curitiba]], in the [[Paraná (state)|State of Paraná]], opened in 2000. {{Coord|-25.4639912|-49.2521676}}
Also, there is a small replica of the statue in [[Belém]], in front of a Belém Importados store, near the city's port.
===Ecuador=== In [[Guayaquil]], a little replica gives the name of "New York" to a neighborhood in the Valle Alto area.
===Peru=== In [[Lima]] the New York Casino in the [[Jesús María District, Lima|Jesús María District]] has a small replica in the main entrance. The casino is a tribute to the state of New York and the USA.
==Asia== ===India=== A small replica can be found in [[Vardhaman Fantasy]], an amusement park in Mira Road, [[Mumbai]] along with other six [[wonders of the world]]. The 7 wonders of the world are made in Eco Park, Kolkata, West Bengal
===Malaysia=== A large replica can be found in [[Genting Highlands]] in the state of [[Pahang]].
===Singapore=== A small replica can be found in [[Haw Par Villa]], a theme park.
===China=== ====Guangzhou==== Set on top of the memorial tomb of "72 Martyrs of Huanghuagang" (see [[Huanghuagang Uprising]]). The current one was re-built in 1981.
====Beijing==== During the [[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989|Tiananmen Square protest of 1989]], Chinese student demonstrators in Beijing built a 10 m (33 ft) image called the ''[[Goddess of Democracy]]'', which sculptor Tsao Tsing-yuan said was intentionally "dissimilar" to the Statue of Liberty to avoid being "too openly pro-American." (See article for a list of replicas of that statue.)
====Shenzhen==== A replica can be found in [[Window of the World]] Park.
===Israel===
A 15 foot high replica of the Statue of Liberty is at the western entrance of the village of [[Arraba, Galilee|Arraba]] in Israel, near a local restaurant.
At a highway intersection in [[Jerusalem]] called "New York Square," there is an abstract skeletal replica of the statue.
===Japan===
The French Statue of Liberty from the [[Île aux Cygnes]] came to [[Odaiba]], [[Tokyo]], from April 1998 to May 1999 in commemoration of "The French year in Japan".<ref name=japantimes /> Because of its popularity, in 2000 a replica of the French Statue of Liberty was erected at the same place. Also in Japan, a small Statue of Liberty is in the [[Amerikamura|Amerika-mura]] (''American Village'') shopping district in [[Osaka]], Japan. Another replica is in [[Oirase, Aomori|Oirase]]<ref>{{cite news |last=Osumi |first=Magdalena |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2013/09/26/events/events-outside-tokyo/floats-make-oirase-fest-a-treat/ |title=Floats make Oirase fest a treat |date=September 26, 2013 |newspaper=[[Japan Times]] |accessdate=October 4, 2015}}</ref> near the town of [[Shimoda, Aomori|Shimoda]] south of [[Misawa, Aomori|Misawa]] in [[Aomori Prefecture]], where the United States has an 8,000-person [[U.S. Air Force]] base. A replica of the Statue of Liberty in [[Ishinomaki, Miyagi|Ishinomaki, Miyagi Prefecture]], was damaged by the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]].<ref>{{cite news |last=MacLeod |first=Calum |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-03-16-japanstruggle16_ST_N.htm |title=Public order still rules amid devastation in Japan |date=March 16, 2011 |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=October 4, 2015}}</ref> There is also a replica in [[Oyabe, Toyama|Oyabe]], [[Toyama Prefecture|Toyama]]. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/%E3%80%92932-0134+Toyama-ken,+Oyabe-shi,+Hirazakura,+%E8%87%AA%E7%94%B1%E3%81%AE%E5%83%8F/@36.8045769,133.3038557,6.8z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x5ff82beb66df6583:0xea33d5b10148d1c6!8m2!3d36.6290409!4d136.8444317|title=Google Maps, 自由の像, Oyabe Toyama|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
===Pakistan=== There are replicas of the Statue of Liberty in [[Bahria Town]], [[Lahore]], and also in [[Bahria Town Phase 8]], [[Islamabad]].
===Philippines=== As early as January 1945, there were already news of a campaign that would help erect a Statue of Liberty replica in the [[Philippines]]. The said monument was supposed to be sponsored by The Chicago Daily Times whose goal was “to commemorate one of the great epics in the struggle for human freedom–the liberation of the Philippines.”
Fast forward to 1950, the Boy Scouts of America was celebrating its 40th anniversary. Jack P. Whitaker, then Scout Commissioner of the Kansas City Area Council, had earlier suggested the creation and distribution of several Statue of Liberty replicas to all American states and territories, including the Philippines.
[[File:Carlos P. Romulo (on the left) and Arthur A. Shuck.jpg|thumb|Chief Scout Executive Arthur A. Shuck presenting to [[Carlos P. Romulo]] a miniature of the Statue of Liberty in April 1950.]]
The eight-foot statues, which were cast in bronze, were distributed all over the U.S. and the world from 1949 to 1951. Almost 200 replicas were delivered to the 39 states of the U.S. and countries such as Panama and Puerto Rico. The [[Boy Scouts of the Philippines]], on the other hand, received its own replica in the early part of 1950.
The statues were donated by the Boy Scouts of America as “an expression of scout brotherhood and goodwill.” Not surprisingly, their 40th anniversary theme was “Strengthen the Arm of Liberty.”
Miniature versions of the statue were also given as gifts. In fact, the Philippines became the first independent nation to receive one of the 4,000 eight-inch statues from the Boy Scouts of America. In April 1950, the said statue was officially given by Chief Scout Executive Arthur A. Shuck to [[Carlos P. Romulo]], then chief of the Philippine Mission to the United Nations.
In the Philippines, several places were suggested as the site where the eight-foot bronze replica would be erected. The task of choosing the perfect site was delegated to the National Urban Planning Commission, and among those it considered were “Engineer Island, atop the proposed reviewing stand on the [[Rizal Park]], and on the center island rotunda between the [[Old Legislative building]] and [[Manila City Hall]].”
In the end, the [[Boy Scouts of the Philippines]] (BSP) erected the statue just outside [[Intramuros]]. As the icon of the United States, the replica of Lady Liberty would survive several attacks by student protesters in the 1960s. It remained standing until the early 1970s, when the BSP decided to transfer it to the Scout Reservation in [[Mt. Makiling]] which would serve as the statue’s home for two decades or so.
In a 2002 article published by the Philippine Star, then BSP PR head Nixon Canlapan revealed that the Statue of Liberty was eventually moved and stored at the BSP headquarters on Concepcion Street (now Natividad Almeda-Lopez) in Ermita, Manila.
Turns out, the American-sponsored replica was not the first Lady Liberty in [[Manila]]. In the 1930s, one of Manila’s biggest shopping stores at that time became the talk of the town not just for its products but also for its unique multi-story building. Located in Juan Luna Street, the L.R. Aguinaldo’s Emporium had an Art Deco facade featuring two contrasting statues: [[Andres Bonifacio]] on the right and the Statue of Liberty on the left.
[[File:Souvenir postcard featuring the L.R. Aguinaldo Building in Juan Luna St., Manila.jpg|thumb|Established by the Philippine retailing pioneer Leopoldo R. Aguinaldo, the L.R. Aguinaldo's Emporium was once one of the biggest shopping stores in pre-war Manila, located in Juan Luna Street, Manila. The multi-story building's facade featured a statue of Andres Bonifacio on the right and a replica of the statue of Liberty on the left.]]
Established by Philippine retailing pioneer Leopoldo R. Aguinaldo, the store would later become known as the Aguinaldo’s Department Store. After the war, Leopoldo’s son Francisco took over the business and the store was moved to Echague.
The Echague branch in the 1950s was known for introducing its customers to quality products both from the Philippines and abroad. It also commissioned young interior designers to update the store’s furniture section. Thus, the store catapulted the careers of famous designers like Myra Cruz, Edgar Ramirez, and Bonnie Ramos, among others. Aguinaldo’s succumbed to the competition and closed in the 1960s. The original building in Juan Luna Street still stands, along with both the Bonifacio and the Liberty statues.
Since the creation of the Liberty statues in Intramuros and Juan Luna Street, other Philippine provinces soon followed suit. Statue of Liberty replicas in can be found in [[Pangasinan]] and as far as [[Camp John Hay]] amphitheater in [[Baguio City]].
===Thailand===
* The Mini Siam and Mini Europe [[Miniature park|model village]], in [[Pattaya]], has a miniature Statue of Liberty amongst others.
===Taiwan=== There are at least two Statue of Liberty replicas (greater than 30 feet in height) in [[Taiwan]]. These two statues are in the cities of [[Keelung]] and [[Taipei]].<ref>{{cite web |author=Sandy H. 何聖欣 |url=http://sandyintaiwan.blogspot.com/2007/08/statues-of-liberty.html#links |title=Sandy's Neipu Notebook: Statues of Liberty |website=Blogspot.com |date=August 30, 2007 |accessdate=July 31, 2012}}</ref>
===Vietnam=== From 1887 to 1945, [[Hanoi]] was home to another copy of the statue. Measuring {{convert|2.85|m|ftin|abbr=on}} tall, it was erected by the French colonial government after being sent from France for an exhibition. It was known to locals unaware of its history as ''[[:vi:Tượng bà đầm xòe|Tượng Bà đầm xòe]]'' (''Statue of the madame saux''). When the French lost control of [[French Indochina]] during World War II, the statue was toppled on August 1, 1945, after being deemed a vestige of the colonial government along with other statues erected by the French.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vietnamnet.vn/thuhanoi/2005/08/474419/ |title=Hà Nội từng có tượng Thần Tự Do trên nóc Tháp Rùa? |trans-title=Has Hanoi ever had the Statue of Liberty on the roof of the Turtle Tower? |website=Vietnam Net |language=Vietnamese |date=1 August 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060708104847/http://www.vietnamnet.vn/thuhanoi/2005/08/474419/ |archivedate=July 8, 2006 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Australia== A 30-foot replica can also be seen at the [[Westfield Marion]] shopping complex in [[Adelaide]], South Australia.

revision.text:
The '''School Meals Initiative for Healthy Children''' (SMI) was an initiative established by the [[United States Department of Agriculture]] in 1994 to revise and update nutrition standards for school meals and require them comply with the Dietary Guidelines for Americans for children over age two. The SMI required school meals to:
* Contain less than 30 percent of calories from fat and 10 percent of calories from saturated fat over the course of a week * Meet one-third of the Recommended Dietary Allowances (RDA) for protein, calcium, iron, vitamin A, vitamin C, and specific levels of calories for specified age groups * Comply with the Dietary Guidelines for Americans for children over the age of 2
The SMI has been superseded by new school nutrition standards set by the [[Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act of 2010]].
==See also== * [[Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act of 2010]] * [[Team Nutrition]] * [[Let's Move!]]

[[File:Communist Block.svg|thumb|250px|States that had communist governments in red, states that the Soviet Union believed at one point to be "moving toward socialism" in orange and other socialist nations in yellow (note that not all of the bright red states remained Soviet allies)]] In the political terminology of the former [[Soviet Union]], the '''socialist-leaning countries''' ({{lang-ru|Страны социалистической ориентации|lit=countries of socialist orientation|translit=Strany sotsialisticheskoy oriyentatsii}}) were the [[post-colonial]] [[Third World]] countries which the Soviet Union recognized as adhering to the ideas of [[State socialism|socialism]] in the [[Marxism–Leninism|Marxist–Leninist]] understanding. As a result, these countries received significant economic and military support.<ref name=tre>[[Dmitri Trenin]] (2011). ''Post-Imperium: A Eurasian Story''. Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. [http://carnegieendowment.org/pdf/book/post-imperium.pdf p. 144].</ref> In Soviet press, these states were also called "countries on the path of the construction of socialism" ({{lang-ru| страны, идущие по пути строительства социализма|translit=strany, idushchiye po puti stroitel'stva sotsializma}}) and countries on the path of the socialist development" ({{lang-ru| страны, стоящие на пути социалиcтического развития|translit=strany, stoyashchiye na puti sotsialicticheskogo razvitiya}}). All these terms meant to draw a distinction from the true [[socialist state]]s (in Marxist–Leninist understanding).<ref name="aes">[http://africa-tur.ru/aboutafrica/741/3186/ "СОЦИАЛИСТИЧЕСКАЯ ОРИЕНТАЦИЯ"]. An article from the 1986–1987 Soviet reference book ''Afrika. Entsiklopedicheskiy spravochnik''.</ref>
The use of the term was partly a result of a reassessment of [[national liberation]] movements in the Third World following World War II, widespread [[decolonization]] and the emergence of the [[Non-Aligned Movement]] as well as [[Nikita Khrushchev]]'s [[Secret Speech]] to the [[20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] and the "[[de-Stalinization]]" of [[Soviet Marxism]].<ref>Tareq, Ismael (2005). ''The Communist Movement in the Arab World''. London. Rutledge. Print. pp. 24–25.</ref> The discussion of anti-colonial struggle at the Second Congress of the [[Comintern]] in 1920 had been formulated in terms of a debate between those for an alliance with the anti-imperialist national bourgeoisie (initially advocated by [[Vladimir Lenin]]) and those for a pure class line of socialist, anti-feudal as well as anti-imperialist struggle (such as [[M. N. Roy]]).<ref>Lenin, V.I. “Report of the Commission on the National and the Colonial Question.” Collected Works, Vol. 31. Moscow: Progress Publishers, 1965. Pp. 213-263. https://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1920/jul/x03.htm</ref> The revolutions of the post-war decolonization era (excepting those led by explicitly proletarian forces, such as the [[Vietnamese Revolution]]), e.g. the rise of [[Nasserism]], were initially seen by many communists as a new form of bourgeois nationalism and there were often sharp conflicts between nationalists and communists.<ref>Ibid. 21.</ref> However, the adoption of “leftist” economic programs (such as [[nationalization]] and/or [[land reform]]) by many of these movements and governments as well as the international alliances between the [[left-wing nationalism|revolutionary nationalists]] and the Soviet Union obliged communists to reassess their nature. These movements were now seen as neither classical bourgeois nationalists nor socialist per se, but rather offering the possibility of "non-capitalist development" as a path of "transition to socialism".<ref>Ibid. 24.</ref>
At various times, these states included [[Algeria]], [[Angola]], [[Central African Republic]], [[Mozambique]], [[Egypt]], [[India]], [[Libya]], [[Ethiopia]], [[South Yemen]] and many others.<ref name=tre/><ref name=aes/> As a major embarrassment to the Soviets, emperor and alleged [[cannibalism|cannibal]] [[Jean-Bédel Bokassa]] of what had been (and later again became) the Central African Republic had at one time had declared his adherence to "scientific socialism" in order to secure the free Soviet economic assistance.<ref>[http://www.occidentaldissent.com/2012/02/02/black-history-month-2012-emperor-bokassas-coronation/ "Black History Month 2012: Emperor Bokassa’s Coronation"].</ref>
In Soviet political science, "socialist orientation" was defined to be an initial period of the development in countries which rejected [[capitalism]], but did not yet have the prerequisites for the socialist revolution or development. Along these lines, a more cautious synonym was used, namely "countries on the path of non-capitalist development". A 1986 Soviet reference book on Africa claimed that about one third of African states followed this path.<ref name=aes/>
In some countries designated "socialist-leaning" by the Soviet Union such as India, this formulation was sharply criticized by emerging [[Maoism|Maoist]] or Chinese-leaning groups, such as the [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]], who considered the doctrine class collaborationist as part of the larger [[Sino-Soviet split]] and the Maoist struggle against so-called Soviet [[Marxist revisionism|revisionism]].
== List of socialist-leaning states == Some of these countries had [[communist government]]s while others (italicized) did not. * ''{{flag|Egypt|1958}} (1954–1973)'' * ''{{flag|Syria}} (1955–1991)'' * ''{{flag|Iraq|1963}} (1958–1963, 1968–1991)'' * ''{{flag|Guinea}} (1960–1978)'' * ''{{flag|Mali}} (1960–1968)'' * {{flagicon|Somalia}} [[Somali Democratic Republic]] (1969–1977; at the outbreak of the [[Ogaden War|Somali invasion of Ethiopia]] in 1977, the Soviet Union ceased to support Somalia, with the corresponding change in rhetoric, but Somalia broke diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union and the United States adopted Somalia as a [[Cold War]] ally)<ref>Crockatt, Richard (1995). ''The Fifty Years War: The United States and the Soviet Union in World Politics''. London and New York City, New York. Routledge. {{ISBN|978-0-415-10471-5}}.</ref> * ''{{flag|Burma|1948}} (1962–1988)'' * ''{{flag|Algeria}} (1962–1990)'' * ''{{flag|Ghana|1964}} (1964–1966)'' * ''{{flag|Peru}} ([[Juan Velasco Alvarado#Military revolution and dictatorship (1968–1975)|1968–1975]])'' * ''{{flag|Sudan}}'' (1968–1972) * ''{{flag|Equatorial Guinea}}'' (1968–1979) * ''{{flag|Libya|1977}} (1969–1991)'' * {{flagicon|Republic of the Congo|1970}} [[People's Republic of the Congo]] (1969–1991) * ''{{flag|Chile}} ([[Presidency of Salvador Allende|1970–1973]])'' * ''{{flag|Cape Verde}} (1975–1991)'' * ''{{flag|Sao Tome and Principe}} (1975–1991)'' * {{flagicon|South Yemen}} [[South Yemen]] (1967–1990) * ''{{flag|Uganda}} (1972–1979)'' * ''{{flagicon|Indonesia}} [[Indonesia]] (1960–1965)'' * ''{{flag|India}} (1955–1989)'' * ''{{flagicon|Bangladesh}} [[People's Republic of Bangladesh]] (1971–1975)'' * ''{{flagicon|Madagascar}} [[Democratic Republic of Madagascar]] (1972–1991)'' * {{flagicon|Guinea Bissau|1973}} [[Guinea Bissau]] (1973–1991) * {{flagicon|Ethiopia|1975}} [[Derg]] (1974–1987) * {{flagicon|Ethiopia|1987}} [[People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia]] (1987–1991) * {{flag|Lao People's Democratic Republic}} (1975–1991) * {{flagicon|Benin|1975}} [[People's Republic of Benin]] (1975–1990) * {{flagicon|Mozambique|1975}} [[People's Republic of Mozambique]] (1975–1990) * {{flagicon|Angola}} [[People's Republic of Angola]] (1975–1991) * ''{{flagicon|Seychelles|1977}} [[Seychelles]] (1977–1991) * {{flagicon|Afghanistan|1980}} [[Democratic Republic of Afghanistan]] (1978–1991) * {{flagicon|Grenada}} [[People's Revolutionary Government (Grenada)]] (1979–1983) * ''{{flag|Nicaragua}} ([[Nicaraguan Revolution|1979–1990]])'' * {{flagicon|Cambodia|1979}} [[People's Republic of Kampuchea]] (1979–1989) * {{flag|Burkina Faso}} (1983–1987)''

The '''Speedy Trial Act of 1974''' (88 Stat. 2080, as amended August 2, 1979, 93 Stat. 328, {{UnitedStatesCode|18|3161|3174}}<ref>[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/part-II/chapter-208 Title 18, Chapter 208 of the United States Code] from the [[Legal Information Institute]]</ref>), establishes time limits for completing the various stages of a federal criminal prosecution.
==Procedural time limits== The Act establishes time limits for completing the various stages of a federal criminal prosecution. The [[Information (formal criminal charge)|information]] or [[indictment]] must be filed within 30 days from the date of arrest or service of the summons.<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|b}}.</ref> Trial must commence within 70 days from the date the information or indictment was filed, or from the date the defendant appears before an officer of the court in which the charge is pending, whichever is later.<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|c|1}}.</ref>
Moreover, in order to ensure that defendants are not rushed to trial without an adequate opportunity to prepare, Congress amended the Act in 1979 to provide a minimum time period during which trial may not commence.<ref>Speedy Trial Act Amendments of 1979, Pub. L. No. 96-43, Section 3, 93 Stat. 327.</ref> Thus, the Act provides that trial may not begin less than 30 days from the date the defendant first appears in court, unless the defendant agrees in writing to an earlier date.<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|c|2}}.</ref> In ''[[United States v. Rojas-Contreras]]'', 474 U.S. 231 (1985), the Supreme Court held that this 30-day trial preparation period is not restarted upon the filing of a substantially similar superseding indictment.
If the indictment is dismissed at the defendant's request, the Act's provisions apply anew upon reinstatement of the charge.<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|d|1}}.</ref> If the indictment is dismissed at the request of the government, the 70-day clock is tolled during the period when no indictment is outstanding, and begins to run again upon the filing of the second indictment.<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|h|6}}.</ref> If trial ends in a mistrial, or the court grants a motion for a new trial, the second trial must begin within 70 days "from the date the action occasioning the retrial becomes final."<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|e|}}.</ref>
===Delays which are not included in the Act=== Certain pretrial delays are automatically excluded from the Act's time limits, such as delays caused by pretrial [[Motion (legal)|motions]].<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|h|1|F}}.</ref> In ''[[Henderson v. United States (1986)|Henderson v. United States]]'', 476 U.S. 321, 330 (1986), the Supreme Court held that {{USCSec|18|3161|h|1|F)}} excludes "all time between the filing of a motion and the conclusion of the hearing on that motion, whether or not a delay in holding that hearing is 'reasonably necessary.'" The Act also excludes a reasonable period (up to 30 days) during which a motion is actually "under advisement" by the court.<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|h|1|J}}.</ref> Other delays excluded from the Act's time limits include delays caused by the unavailability of the defendant or an essential witness ({{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|h|3}}); delays attributable to a co-defendant ({{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|h|7|}}); and delays attributable to the defendant's involvement in other proceedings, including delay resulting from an [[interlocutory appeal]].<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|h|1|E}}.</ref> (Note, however, that the 30-day defense preparation period provided for in {{USCSub2|18|3161|c|2}} is calculated without reference to Section {{USCSub2|18|3161|h}} exclusions).
A defendant may not expressly waive his rights under the Speedy Trial Act.<ref>See, e.g., ''United States v. Saltzman'', 984 F.2d 1087, 1090-1092 (10th Cir. 1993).</ref> However, if the trial judge determines that the "ends of justice" served by a continuance outweigh the interest of the public and the defendant in a speedy trial, the delay occasioned by such continuance is excluded from the Act's time limits.<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|h|8|A}}.</ref> The judge must set forth, orally or in writing, his or her reasons for granting the continuance.<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|h|8|A}}.</ref>
The Act provides a sanction of [[Involuntary dismissal|dismissal]] for violation of its time limits that may be with or without prejudice to reprosecution. In assessing whether dismissal should be with prejudice, the court must consider the seriousness of the offense, the circumstances leading to dismissal, and the impact that reprosecution would have on the administration of the Act and on the administration of justice.<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3161|a|1}}–{{USCSub2|18|3161|a|2}}.</ref> In ''[[United States v. Taylor]]'', 487 U.S. 326 (1988), the Supreme Court held that a trial court must examine each statutory factor in deciding to dismiss charges with prejudice. The Court in Taylor found that a minor violation of the time limitations of the act that did not prejudice the defendant's trial preparation did not justify the dismissal with prejudice of an indictment charging serious drug offenses.
While a defendant cannot unilaterally waive his rights under the Speedy Trial Act, he can forfeit his right to obtain a dismissal of the case for a claimed violation of the Act by failing to move for dismissal prior to trial. The statute provides that "[f]ailure of the defendant to move for dismissal prior to trial...shall constitute a waiver of the right to dismissal under this section."<ref>{{UnitedStatesCodeSub|18|3162|a|2}}.</ref>
==Juvenile proceedings== The Speedy Trial Act is inapplicable to [[juvenile delinquency]] proceedings, which have their own speedy trial provision.<ref>See {{UnitedStatesCode|18|5036}} (speedy trial provision of the Juvenile Delinquency Act)</ref> Furthermore, the Interstate Agreement on Detainers (IAD) provides its own time limits for persons incarcerated in other jurisdictions.<ref>See [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/html/uscode18a/usc_sec_18a_01000002----000-.html 18 U.S.C. Appendix 2, § 2], Articles III-VI.</ref> In such a case, the government must comply with both the time limits of the IAD and the Speedy Trial Act.
==Constitutional basis== {{main|Speedy Trial Clause}}
A defendant's right to a speedy trial has constitutional and statutory underpinnings in addition to the Speedy Trial Act.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Aaron|title=What are Speedy Trial Rights|url=https://www.expertlaw.com/library/criminal-law/what-are-speedy-trial-rights|website=ExpertLaw|accessdate=18 March 2018|date=31 August 2016}}</ref> Federal statutes of limitations provide a time frame within which charges must be filed. Moreover, Rule {{frcrp|48}} of the [[Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure]], grants trial courts discretion to dismiss cases that are not brought to trial promptly.<ref>See Rule {{frcrp|48}}(b), Fed. R. Crim. P. (authorizing trial court to dismiss indictment if there is "unnecessary delay" in presenting the charge to a grand jury, in filing an information, or in bringing a defendant to trial).</ref>
Even if a charge is brought within the period provided by the statute of limitations, a defendant may be able to show that preaccusation delay has violated his or her [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment]] due process rights. To obtain a dismissal of the charges by reason of pre-indictment delay, a defendant has the burden of establishing that the government engaged in intentional delay to gain a tactical advantage, and that he suffered actual prejudice.<ref>''[[United States v. Lovasco]]'', 431 U.S. 783 (1977); ''[[United States v. Marion]]'', 404 U.S. 307, 324 (1971).</ref>
A defendant's rights under the [[Speedy Trial Clause]] of the [[Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Sixth Amendment]] are triggered by "either a formal indictment or information or else the actual restraints imposed by arrest and holding to answer a criminal charge."<ref>''United States v. Marion'', 404 U.S. 307, 320 (1971).</ref> (As noted above, any delay before this time must be scrutinized under the [[Due Process Clause]] of the Fifth Amendment, not the Sixth Amendment's Speedy Trial Clause.<ref>''[[United States v. MacDonald]]'', 456 U.S. 1, 7 (1982)).</ref> In ''[[Barker v. Wingo]]'', 407 U.S. 514 (1972), the Supreme Court set out a four-factor test for determining whether delay between the initiation of criminal proceedings and the beginning of trial violates a defendant's Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial. The test requires the court to consider the length of the delay, the cause of the delay, the defendant's assertion of his or her right to a speedy trial, and the presence or absence of prejudice resulting from the delay.<ref>[[Barker v. Wingo]], 407 U.S. at 530-533.</ref>
In ''[[United States v. Loud Hawk]]'', 474 U.S. 302 (1986), where the reason for the 90-month delay (interlocutory appeals) did not weigh against the government, the Supreme Court held that the possibility of prejudice occasioned by the delay was not sufficient to establish a Sixth Amendment speedy trial violation. Moreover, the courts of appeals routinely reject Sixth Amendment speedy trial challenges in the absence of a showing of prejudice.<ref>See, e.g., ''United States v. Tannehill'', 49 F.3d 1049, 1054 (5th Cir.), cert. denied, 116 S. Ct. 167 (1995); United States v. Baker, 63 F.3d 1478, 1497 (9th Cir. 1995), cert. denied, 116 S. Ct. 824 (1996).</ref> However, in ''[[Doggett v. United States]]'', 505 U.S. 647 (1992), the Supreme Court held that an "extraordinary" eight-and-one-half-year delay between the defendant's indictment and arrest, which resulted from the government's "egregious persistence in failing to prosecute [him]," violated his right to a speedy trial even in the absence of "affirmative proof of particularized prejudice."<ref>[[Doggett v. United States]], 505 U.S. at 652, 655, 657.</ref>
Where there are successive state and federal prosecutions, the general rule is that the federal constitutional speedy trial right does not arise until a federal accusation against the defendant is made. Thus, a prior state arrest based on the same facts as the subsequent federal charge does not implicate the federal constitutional guarantee.<ref>''United States v. Walker'', 710 F.2d 1062, 1069 (5th Cir. 1983), cert. denied, 465 U.S. 1005 (1984).</ref>

Speedy Trial Act of 1974] from the Criminal Resource Manual of the United States Attorneys' Office
